53.backgroundRationale: As described in SSO1 and SSO2, data collection and analysis in the South Fork Salmon River (SFSR) and Lemhi River are unified within a watershed model (QCInc 2005). The focus of ISEMP implementation in the SFSR is the development and testing of metrics and protocols to support habitat and population status and trend monitoring. Given the passive nature of habitat restoration actions implemented in the SFSR (see SSO1) and current hatchery supplementation effecting two of the three spring/summer Chinook salmon populations (see SSO1), a model-based approach was adopted as a means to partition variance contributed to freshwater productivity from hatchery releases in order to improve our ability to relate freshwater productivity to passive changes in habitat quality and quantity. The SFSR also provides an opportunity to test the impacts of spring/summer Chinook salmon supplementation on freshwater productivity of two listed and un-supplemented steelhead populations. Data collection in the SFSR includes four major components: 1. Probabilistically distributed remote juvenile capture/recapture and tagging efforts. 2. Probabilistically distributed habitat surveys. 3. Operation of rotary screw traps for the purposes of abundance estimation and as a re-sight opportunity for fish tagged in capture/recapture and tagging efforts. 4. Instream PIT tag arrays.

56.backgroundRationale: The ISEMP has designed a robust and flexible implementation and monitoring strategy that will implement the full suite of restoration actions in the lower 26 miles of the Entiat River in a 10-year time period, maximize the resolution of effects from different action types and reveal multi-scale mechanisms (e.g., effects of action types, geomorphic reaches, landuse), and detect a response at a lower resolution (i.e., watershed scale) if a higher resolution is not possible due to, for example, implementation of restoration actions outside the experimental design. This dsign is described in the Entiat IMW Implementation Stategy, Appendix B to the Upper Columbia Implementation Strategy (Hillman. 2006). The Entiat IMW will answer the following questions: 1) Did habitat restoration improve freshwater productivity at the watershed scale? 2) What was the impact of the varying restoration types? (Supports the Upper Columbia Salmon Recovery Board’s Adaptive Management Framework). 3) What were the mechanisms by which physical habitat changes improved freshwater productivity? The goals of the Entiat IMW are to: 1) Determine if the implementation of proposed instream and side-channel habitat restoration actions between river miles 0 and 26 significantly improve the abundance and productivity of spring Chinook and steelhead, two of four Viable Salmonid Population metrics (VSP, McElhany et al. 2000) used to measure “recovery” as identified in the Recovery Plan (UCSRB 2007). 2) Determine if the implementation of proposed instream and side-channel habitat restoration actions between river miles 0 and 26 significantly improve metrics specified in the 2008 FCRPS BiOp.

62.backgroundRationale: Because pre-treatment data for much of the fish and habitat responses to fencing do not exist, only post-treatment evaluations can be made. In order to discern patterns from noisy data, we need to provide stark contrasts to illuminate the effects of fencing on streams. The approach ISEMP has used is to find an on-fenced (control) reach on the same stream in very close proximity to the reach that has been fenced (treatment). We believe this is the most appropriate approach to control for factors that affect fish and habitat responses, where differences between treatment and control are driven mainly by changes due to the exclusion of livestock. For example, stream width can be influenced by grazers through trampling of banks and the removal of riparian vegetation. Stream width, however,is also a function of drainage area, geology type, precipitation type and amount, among other factors. Similarly, the abundance of juvenile steelhead is dependent on the number of spawners returning to a stream, which is in part due to out-of- watershed effects such as ocean condition, climatic condition and mainstem experiences. In both examples, these factors are more likely to be similar between treatment and control reaches in close proximity, than if comparison were made between reaches in different streams.

62.keyAssumptions:
An extensive review of grazing literature aligned the study’s site selection to be based on the following criteria:
- Streams with salmonids. 
- The stream must be wadable. 
- Knowledge of the history of the exclosure (grazing records). 
- Sites are contiguous ungrazed exclosures and unfenced grazed reaches adjacent to each other. 
- Sites are not inclusive of or directly adjacent to mining operations or water diversion reservoirs. 
- Sites should have limited human implemented restoration (i.e. check dams, logs steps, in-channel structures, rip rap or mass vegetative bank stabilization.) 
- No significant tributaries should intervene between the treatment and control reaches. 
- Channel reaches shall be as geomorphically similar as possible and shall not have major bedrock constraints. Geomorphic attributes shall include streams with similar valley confinement, valley slope, and elevation. 
- For the purposes of our study, landowner permission will play a critical role in site selection. Exclosures in the John Day Basin are installed on both private and public lands. 

When exclosures are installed on private lands, the property is leased and maintained by the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, but activities outside the realm of routine fence maintenance must be approved by the landowner. After the lease of the enclosure expires, the exclosure reverts back to the sole ownership of the landowner, unless a lease renewal is agreed upon. If the landowner decides to not renew his lease, he may deny any further access to his property.

65.backgroundRationale: One of the main purposes of a monitoring program is to detect changes in a particular variable of interest over time. Serious concerns have been raised about the ability of many fish and stream habitat monitoring programs to detect biologically meaningful changes due to confounding factors such as high natural variability in many ecological variables, poorly designed monitoring programs, inconsistent monitoring protocols, and low statistical power (Larsen et al. 2004, Roni et al. 2008). ISEMP has developed a hierarchical- staircase experimental design for the implementation of the proposed restoration action.

68.backgroundRationale: The goal of the Salmon ISEMP project is to measure the freshwater productivity of salmonids for the purposes of evaluating the effectiveness of habitat actions at improving freshwater productivity and to determine the relationships between status and trends in habitat quality and availability and status and trends of salmonid freshwater productivity. Effectively measuring freshwater productivity is complicated by the fact the distribution of juvenile salmonids is largely unknown for much of their life history. Further, until recently, the application of unique marks has been largely limited to juveniles greater than 60mm fork length. In order to address these complexities, juvenile sampling associated with the Salmon ISEMP is distributed using a spatially-balanced design (generalized random tessellation survey (GRTS). This protocol focuses on how sampling effort is distributed, criteria for rejecting probabilistically selected sites, and methods for juvenile capture and tagging at remaining sites.
objectives:
1. Estimate life-stage specific population estimates at the site and tributary scale
2. Estimate survival at multiple temporal and spatial scales including tributary and watershed.

68.qualityControlConsiderations: All data is checked during field entry using controls on the hand-held datalogger. Once in the database, data quality is maintained using standardized queries.
68.reportingConsiderations: Yearly reports, data storage into regional databases such as PTAGIS.

Resposible for final data qa/qc and draft reporting. Lead Field Technician - responsible for field crew day-to-day activities, and direct sampling of fish Field Technician - applies protocol direct collecting fish.

71.backgroundRationale: The Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP) is an ongoing collaborative effort to design, test, implement and evaluate Status and Trends Monitoring for salmon and steelhead populations and their habitat and watershed-scale Effectiveness Monitoring for management actions impacting salmon and steelhead populations and habitat in the Interior Columbia River Basin. ISEMP takes a pilot-project approach to the research and development of monitoring by implementing experimental programs in several major subbasins of the Interior Columbia. Population-specific and aggregate estimates of juvenile abundance and survival will be estimated using information obtained from the recapture of juveniles PIT tagged during remote tagging surveys. Recapture data for tagged individuals will be derived from interrogations at extended length PIT tag arrays and from recapture at tributary rotary screw traps. The multi-scale nature of this goal requires the standardization of protocols and sampling designs that are statistically valid and powerful, properties that are currently inconsistent across the multiple monitoring programs in the region. This smolt trapping and trap efficiency monitoring protocol is a component of the overall ISEMP, and while it stands alone as an important contribution to the management of anadromous salmonids and their habitat, it also plays a key role within ISEMP as it is built on a standardized format following Oakley et al. (2003) that all of the ISEMP protocols adhere to. Downstream migrant trapping of juvenile salmonid can be a valuable tool to estimate relative abundance, production, size, survival, migration timing and behavior (Volkhardt et al. 2007). Of significance to status, trend and effectiveness monitoring programs, simple mark-recapture methods can be used with downstream migrant traps to estimate total freshwater production, and enable the estimation of mortality or survival between life stages (e.g., egg-to-smolt).
objectives: 1. Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead production in S.Fk. Salmon R.tributaries
2.  Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead survival in S.Fk. Salmon R.tributaries

77.backgroundRationale: The Salmon River Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Project (ISEMP) is part of a larger Research, Monitoring and Evaluation (RME) Pilot Project initiative that, in addition to work being conducted in the Salmon River basin, includes ongoing activities in the Wenatchee/Entiat and John Day River subbasins. The motivation for the RME Pilot Project has two major components – consolidation of regional RME planning efforts, and pilot-scale implementation of RME design concepts. At its core, the ISEMP Project is an experimental approach to the development of status, trends and effectiveness monitoring for salmonid populations, habitat characteristics and tributary environment management actions. Thus, the primary motivation is not the implementation of long-term monitoring programs, rather, the development and testing of programs that are supportable in the long-term by the natural resource co-manager community. Thus the major accomplishments of the project will be monitoring approaches that address key management questions and data collection and reduction processes to meet critical regional decision making needs. The primary goal of the Lemhi Effectiveness Project is to identify and quantify the effects of habitat modifications on the productivity and survival of focal anadromous and resident salmonids within the Lemhi watershed. For anadromous species, tributary or reach specific juvenile abundance will be estimated by partitioning recaptures at existing mainstem screw traps. Total abundance will be estimated by the screw traps, and the total estimate will be partitioned to tributaries or reaches. Juvenile survival will be estimated by evaluating overall systemwide recapture efficiency, generated by common PIT tag detections at upper and lower screw traps, and by determining the fraction of fish that passed PIT tag arrays.
objectives: 1. Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead production in the Lemhi River
2.  Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead survival in the Lemhi River

80.backgroundRationale: The Integrated Status adn Effectiveness Monitoring Program has a lead biometrician that assists ISEMP cooperators data and GIS analysts in interpretation and statistical analysis of data. The biometrician collaborates with ISEMP technical staff to extract information from existing data sets to: (i) understand the role monitoring methods play in determining data quality and utility; (ii) develop recommendations on monitoring methods; (iii) develop models to identify limiting factors and guide resource management decision making; and (iv) develop a data analysis framework that will form the basis of future data collection and management efforts. The data analysis component of the project will require significant data reduction, description, and summarization through standard univariate and multivariate approaches. More intensive statistical applications may be required to explain complex interactions, such as classification and regression trees (CART), multivariate adaptive regression splines (MARS) analyses, and Structural Equation Modeling.
objectives: Provide technical and analytical support to ISEMP staff and cooperators
80.keyAssumptions: Analytical Approaches assumed used: - Multivariate and univariate statistical models of salmonid habitat and population data. - Spatial / temporal variance decomposition based salmonid habitat and population data analysis - Landscape-scale classification system for salmonid habitat for fish-habitat data analysis support - structural equation modeling of salmonid habitat and population data

89.backgroundRationale:
Objectives of the steelhead redd surveys are to: 1) Enumerate steelhead redds within index areas or within random sites. 2) Detect trends of redd abundance and distribution within larger reaches based upon enumeration of steelhead in index areas, and estimate adult populations. 3) Identify steelhead spawning timing in the Entiat and Wenatchee River subbasins.

This protocol includes methods for sighting redds and spawners.
objectives: Standardize surveys used to determine abundance and distribution of steelhead redds in the Upper Columbia Basin.
89.qualifications: The investigator should be familiar with the size of redds or nests produced by other species of fish that may be spawning at the time the surveys are conducted to be able to distinguish between redds of the target species and redds of other species.
89.safetyConsiderations: Crew should be familiar with safety procedures when working around streams.
89.fieldScheduleNotes: Steelhead spawning is thought to begin when water temperatures are near 4.00C and generally progresses upstream following favorable water temperatures. It is important that the first survey occurs just prior to the expected onset of steelhead spawning so that subsequent surveys count only newly formed steelhead redds. The survey is complete when no new redds have been detected for two consecutive surveys. Redd surveys are conducted by two-member teams on foot or by rafting in the spawning areas. Surveys are conducted in a downstream manner, taking care not to disturb spawning fish.
89.name: ISEMP Field Manual of Scientific Protocols for Steelhead Redd Surveys within the Upper Columbia Monitoring Strategy Copy v1.0

95.backgroundRationale:
Downstream migrant trapping of juvenile salmonid can be a valuable tool to estimate relative abundance, production, size, survival, migration timing and behavior (Volkhardt et al. 2007). Of significance to status, trend and effectiveness monitoring programs, simple mark-recapture methods can be used with downstream migrant traps to estimate total freshwater production, and enable the estimation of mortality or survival between life stages (e.g., egg-to-smolt) (Volkhardt et al. 2007). The objectives for juvenile trapping activities are to estimate abundance (production), size and condition for populations or subgroups of anadromous salmonid stocks. Additionally, the operation of rotary screw traps provides an opportunity to deploy tags in captured juveniles to estimate out-of-subbasin survival. These goals are consistent with the Upper Columbia Monitoring Strategy (UCMS, Hillman 2006).

The objectives for juvenile trapping activities are to estimate abundance (production), size and condition for populations or subgroups of anadromous salmonid stocks. Additionally, the operation of rotary screw traps provides an opportunity to deploy tags into target species.
objectives: The objectives for juvenile trapping activities are to estimate abundance, size and condition for populations or subgroups of anadromous salmonid stocks.
Collection of genetic samples to support genetic analysis of the species
95.dataHandlingConsiderations: Field practitioners should be careful to avoid transposing errors when writing and entering data, and should be sure that all data are clearly legible. In the case that data is entered into datasheets in the field practitioners should be in the practice of making photocopies of data sheets, and designating a copy as the Master Copy. The Master Copy can be edited by reviewers using red ink who should initialize and date any edits.
95.qualityControlConsiderations: Standardizing methods used for mark-recapture trap efficiency trials is important for meaningful and comparable estimates of trap efficiency and total abundance of downstream migrants.
95.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: When using a rotary screw trap daily measurements should be taken to ensure the rotational velocity of the trap cone is operating within the desired range. Clean the trap and live well of accumulated organic debris at each site visit. Inspect the trap to ensure it is functioning properly and has not been damaged and record the trap status.
95.qualifications: Crew Lead: Must be able to manage and train Crew Members, identify fish to species, be trained to handle and tag fish. Crew Member: Must be able to identify fish species and be trained to handle and tag fish.
95.trainingRequirements: Each monitoring agency is responsible for training the personnel who will be running the traps, carrying out the capture, handling and PIT tagging of the fish, and loading the data into P3 and uploading the data to an ATM and to PTAGIS. Crew members need to be trained to handle fish according to protocols.
95.safetyConsiderations: Each monitoring agency is responsible for training the personnel who will be running the traps, carrying out the capture, handling and PIT tagging of the fish, and loading the data into P3 and uploading the data to an ATM and to PTAGIS.
95.name: Modified ISEMP Field Manual of Scientific Protocols for Downstream Migrant Trapping, with DNA sampling v1.0

98.backgroundRationale:
Stream channel incision is one cause of riparian zone degradation in the arid western United States. Channel incision may be initiated by factors such as major floods, changes in sediment regimes, urban development, and channelization (Rosgen, 1997). As the stream bed becomes progressively deeper, the channel can contain large peak flows and the stream can no longer dissipate energy, water, and materials across its former floodplains (Simon and Rinaldi, 2006). This reduces the area for surface water and groundwater exchange, and aquifer infiltration and water table elevation decline (Brunke and Gonser, 1997). Therefore, streambed degradation is associated with reduced groundwater recharge, reduced reliability and consistency of baseflow, and damaged hyporheic zone connections (Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014). Riparian vegetation that relies on high water tables may also be undercut or stressed (Scott et al., 1999; Shafroth et al., 2000). Ultimately, this impairs stream channel habitat by isolating it from the floodplain, limiting nutrient cycling, and increasing water temperatures (due to lack of shade and poor hyporheic exchange), with negative effects on both in-stream and riparian biota (reviewed in Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014).

Channel incision may be mitigated if beaver return and build dams on streams (Pollock et al., 2007). Pollock et al. (2014) describe how beaver dams can greatly accelerate the channel recovery process by promoting trench widening and aggradation. Beaver dams are an integral part of the restoration strategy currently underway in Bridge Creek, a tributary to the John Day River in eastern Oregon, USA, where channel incision limits habitat quantity and quality for a population of threatened, wild Mid Columbia River steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss) (Pollock et al., 2012 Pollock et al. 2015). In 2009, beaver dam analog (BDA) structures were installed to increase the number and lifespan of beaver dams on Bridge Creek.  One hypothesis of the Bridge Creek restoration approach is that water table elevation will increase as surface water elevations rise due to beaver dam impoundments and ongoing sedimentation and bed aggradation (Figure 1); these changes are also expected to enhance groundwater recharge by increasing the duration and extent of floodplain inundation (Pollock et al., 2012).

Wells drilled into floodplain surfaces allow access to groundwater, and data loggers can be deployed to monitor hourly changes in temperature and pressure.  Pressure changes can be transformed into water table elevation data using computer software. This protocol and methods were used to monitoring changes in groundwater elevation and temperature in two well fields in the Bridge Creek Intensively Monitoring Watershed. One well field is adjacent to a restored reach treated with BDA structures (treatment), while the second well field is adjacent to an unrestored, reference reach (control). The purpose of groundwater monitoring was to determine whether trends in water table elevation and groundwater temperature support the hypothesis that restoration actions enhance groundwater recharge and improve hydrologic connections between the stream and its floodplain, mitigating the effects of channel incision.
objectives: Monitor hourly changes in water table elevation and groundwater temperature in well fields adjacent to a restored stream reach (treatment) and a nearby unrestored, reference stream reach (control)
Determine whether trends in water table elevation and groundwater temperature support the hypothesis that restoration actions have improved hydrologic connectivity and mitigated effects of incision
98.keyAssumptions:
• The reference site provides an appropriate control scenario
  • The depth and spatial locations of the groundwater wells are appropriate for detecting changes in water table elevation and groundwater temperature resulting from restoration activities
  • Long term differences in water table elevation trajectories and groundwater temperature patterns recorded from the two instrumented well fields are attributable to their treated vs. reference status
  • Data loggers are calibrated and functioning properly
  • Field measurement data for each well (well elevations, cap perch measurements, and cable length measurements) are accurate
98.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are managed in Desktop-level MS Access databases and backed up to the cloud. Highly recommend database use for managing sensor data. Data are downloaded from the loggers twice per year. Recommend upload to the master database within 1 week of data collection, in order to identify and resolve any potential errors.
98.qualityControlConsiderations: Field technicians measure certain variables at each well that should change very little between monitoring events, including the cap perch height (the height of the groundwater well above the land surface) and the length of the cable to which the logger is attached. These variables can therefore be cross-checked between monitoring events both in the field and in the master database, to ensure that these measurements are accurate. Data upload forms utilize drop-down lists, database queries, and programming scripts that minimize the amount of data that is input to the master database by hand (Figure 3). This helps prevent data entry errors. Finally, the data entry form is equipped with programming scripts that are designed to check for anomalous information (e.g., water tables that are higher than the land surface) and for duplicate data entries (Figure 3).
98.reportingConsiderations: There are no specific reporting formats or time frames.
98.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Logger batteries are checked twice per year and last about 4-5 years. When the batteries die, the loggers can be sent to the manufacturer (Onset) for battery replacement and logger calibration.
98.rolesAndResponsibilities: Crew Lead: Project manager(s) - review study results and author reports Crew Members: Field technician - downloads groundwater logger data and performs well maintenance twice per year, updates field protocols Data manager - prepares and uploads groundwater logger data to the master database; maintains database integrity, updates data management protocols Statistician - completes data analysis
98.qualifications: Field technician(s) should be able to operate a laptop and the appropriate software and hardware required for logger downloads. Technicians need to be able to use a measuring tape and basic tools (such as bolt cutters and crimpers) required to complete well maintenance. Data manager(s) must have appropriate background knowledge of database software including Microsoft Excel and Access. Statistician(s) must have advanced knowledge in developing statistical models, as well as a working knowledge of how to apply those concepts and analyze data in statistical software such as R.
98.trainingRequirements: Field technician training requirements: Training in the field protocols associated with groundwater logger download and well maintenance. This includes activities such as: retrieving loggers from wells, utilizing logger hardware and software to download monitoring data, saving data in appropriate file structures, measuring relevant variables such as cap perch height and cable length, evaluating the condition of wells and loggers, and applying appropriate maintenance as needed, including making well repairs or replacing worn/damages cables. Data manager training requirements: Training in the data management protocols associated with groundwater data upload. This includes developing a working knowledge of the master Access database, and a demonstrated ability to add data to and query data from the database accurately. The data manager should also be able to recognize and fix data anomalies.
98.safetyConsiderations: General common sense in the field and appropriate use of the tools and equipment are all that is required. There are no specifically hazardous locations, equipment, or chemicals required to complete the monitoring.
98.fieldScheduleNotes: Loggers checked and downloaded twice per year. Recommend downloads occur before high flows in spring and in the fall post-summer dry periods to ensure data is captured during critical high flow and summer temp windows.
98.budgetConsiderations: Cost estimates include purchase of initial monitoring equipment (data loggers). Per year monitoring costs once equipment has been purchased drops to <$1,000 per site/year.

99.backgroundRationale:
Stream channel incision is one cause of riparian zone degradation in the arid western United States. Channel incision may be initiated by factors such as major floods, changes in sediment regimes, urban development, and channelization (Rosgen, 1997). As the stream bed becomes progressively deeper, the channel can contain large peak flows and the stream can no longer dissipate energy, water, and materials across its former floodplains (Simon and Rinaldi, 2006). This reduces the area for surface water and groundwater exchange, and aquifer infiltration and water table elevation decline (Brunke and Gonser, 1997). Therefore, streambed degradation is associated with reduced groundwater recharge, reduced reliability and consistency of baseflow, and damaged hyporheic zone connections (Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014). Riparian vegetation that relies on high water tables may also be undercut or stressed (Scott et al., 1999; Shafroth et al., 2000). Ultimately, this impairs stream channel habitat by isolating it from the floodplain, limiting nutrient cycling, and increasing water temperatures (due to lack of shade and poor hyporheic exchange), with negative effects on both in-stream and riparian biota (reviewed in Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014).

Channel incision may be mitigated if beaver return and build dams on streams (Pollock et al., 2007). Pollock et al. (2014) describe how beaver dams can greatly accelerate the channel recovery process by promoting trench widening and aggradation. In 2009, beaver dam analog (BDA) structures were installed to increase the number and lifespan of beaver dams on Bridge Creek.  One hypothesis of the Bridge Creek restoration approach is that water table elevation will increase as surface water elevations rise due to beaver dam impoundments and ongoing sedimentation and bed aggradation (Figure 1); these changes are also expected to enhance groundwater recharge by increasing the duration and extent of floodplain inundation (Pollock et al., 2012).

One well field is adjacent to a restored reach treated with BDA structures (treatment), while the second well field is adjacent to an unrestored, reference reach (control). The purpose of groundwater monitoring was to determine whether trends in water table elevation and groundwater temperature support the hypothesis that restoration actions enhance groundwater recharge and improve hydrologic connections between the stream and its floodplain, mitigating the effects of channel incision.
objectives: Monitor hourly changes in water table elevation and groundwater temperature in well fields adjacent to a restored stream reach (treatment) and a nearby unrestored, reference stream reach (control)
Determine whether trends in water table elevation and groundwater temperature support the hypothesis that restoration actions have improved hydrologic connectivity and mitigated effects of incision

sampleDesigns.title: Lower Granite Dam adult steelhead and Chinook salmon scale ageing (Priorities 4.3 - 4.4) - Quantitative Consultants Inc 1

101.backgroundRationale:
The ISEMP is a collaborative effort to 1) design, test, implement and evaluate Status and Trends Monitoring for salmon and steelhead populations and their habitat and 2) conduct watershed-scale Effectiveness Monitoring for management actions impacting salmon and steelhead populations and habitat in the Interior Columbia River Basin. ISEMP takes a pilot-project approach to the research and development of monitoring by implementing experimental programs in several major sub-basins of the Interior Columbia.

Annual estimates of abundance and productivity at a variety of scales (e.g., tributary, sub-population, population, Major Population Group [MPG], ESU/DPS) are critical to monitoring the status and trends of listed salmon and steelhead species (McElhaney et al. 2000, Crawford and Rumsey 2011). This protocol describes how the ISEMP uses the observation window located on the Lower Granite Dam (LGR) adult fish ladder and the adult trap at the LGR Adult Fish Facility (LGR) to estimate wild escapement of adult steelhead and sp/sum Chinook salmon migrating past LGR. Moreover, we describe a status, trends, and action effectiveness monitoring program that uses the adult trap at LGR to PIT tag adult steelhead and sp/sum Chinook salmon and uses subsequent upstream interrogations/detections of PIT tagged adults to decompose the escapement past LGR into MPG, population, subpopulation, and tributary estimates of escapement. Tissue and scale samples collected at the time of tagging enable escapement estimates to be further partitioned by sex and age. Estimates of total abundance and abundance by sex and age over time allows estimation of productivity.
objectives: Describe methods to estimate total natural origin spring/summer Chinook salmon and steelhead escapement past LGR.
Document methods for the PIT tagging and tissue and scale sampling of adults at the LGR Adult Fish Facility.
Describe methods to decompose the runs-at-large past LGR into MPG, population, subpopulation, and tributary estimates of escapement.
101.keyAssumptions:
Primarily standard assumptions accompanying mark/recapture models:

1. the tagged population is representative of the un-tagged population

2. tagging does not appreciably change behavior or increase mortality 

3. tagged individuals have an equal probability of detection

4. tagged individuals do not lose their 'mark'
101.dataHandlingConsiderations: Window count data at LGR are provided by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and are available from the Columbia Basin Research Data Access in Real Time (DART) website (www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_daily). Subsequent PIT tag detection/observation data are available at the PIT Tag Information System (PTAGIS, www.ptagis.org). Sex, age, and PBT data for PIT tagged individuals are available in a Lower Granite Dam SQL trapping database (LGTrappingDB) developed and maintained by the Idaho Department of Fish and Game. Each of these databases provides rigorous QA/QC procedures to minimize data recording errors.
101.qualityControlConsiderations: DART and PTAGIS queries are the primary means of obtaining data. The Idaho Department of Fish and Game can also provide data of known quality. This protocol is intended to produce annual estimates of escapement, in-season estimates are unlikely to be reliable.
101.reportingConsiderations: This protocol is intended to produce annual estimates of escapement, in-season estimates are unlikely to be reliable. Estimates are provided in written technical reports produced by ISEMP collaborators.
101.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Scissors used to take tissue samples at the Lower Granite Dam Adult Fish Facility are rinsed with water between samples to reduce risk of DNA cross-contamination.
101.rolesAndResponsibilities: Window Count Data: Window observers are responsible for enumerating, by species, fish passing the observation window located on the Lower Granite Dam adult fish ladder during fish counting hours. These operation are overseen by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and made available at the Columbia Basin Research Data Access in Real Time (DART) website (www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_daily). Adult Trap Data: A crew lead, provided by the National Marine Fisheries Service, oversees operation of the Lower Granite Dam adult trap operations. Crew members consist of technicians provided by collaborating agencies involved in trap operation. Crew members are in charge of daily trap operation including processing of all adults captured daily in the adult trap. Crew members visually inspect fish for any visible marks/tags, implant unclipped adult steelhead and sp/sum Chinook salmon into individuals not already containing a PIT tag, measure and record length and weight, collect scale and tissue samples for post-hoc age and genetic analysis, and return fish to the adult ladder to resume upstream migration. All crew members accurately record data on paper and electronic data forms. PIT Interrogation/Detection Data: The majority of upstream PIT tag observation and detection data are collected passively at Instream PIT Tag Detection Systems (IPTDS) operated throughout the Snake River basin. Operation of these IPTDS is overseen by multiple collaborating agencies and are generally managed by fisheries biologists with assistance from fisheries technicians. Data may also be collected at weirs operated by various collaborating agencies; weirs are generally operated by trained fisheries technicians with help from fisheries biologists as needed. Data Analysis: The model to estimate total wild escapement past Lower Granite Dam and Hierarchical Patch Occupancy model are typically run by a biometrician or scientist with an M.S. or PhD in Fishery Sciences or related field.
101.qualifications: Adult Trap Data: The crew lead at the Lower Granite Dam adult trap ladder is generally and experienced fish biologist with experience handling and processing large numbers of salmonids. Trap technicians are hired by a variety of collaborating agencies and are generally fisheries technicians attending college or with a B.S. in natural resources, fisheries, or a related field. Fisheries technicians should be organized and have excellent fish handling and data recording skills. Operators and maintainers of IPTDS are generally fisheries biologists with experience in installation and operation of IPTDS. Fisheries technicians may also assist with installation and maintenance of IPTDS. The models to estimate total wild escapement past Lower Granite Dam or the Hierarchical Patch Occupancy Model to estimate escapement to locations throughout the Snake River basin are generally developed by a biometrician or scientist with a background in statistics, mark-recpature models, model fitting, etc and with experience in computer programming.
101.trainingRequirements: Window observers at the Lower Granite Dam adult fish facility should be trained and well experienced at identifying fish by species. The crew lead at the LGR Adult Fish Facility should be well trained and experienced in fish handling, processing, and data collection and have excellent leadership and problem solving skills. The crew lead should provide training to crew members working at the facility. Crew members are generally technicians with training and experience in fish handling and data recording. Fisheries technicians should have excellent data recording skills. Operation of the models to estimate total wild escapement at LGR and escapement to locations throughout the Snake River basin are generally biometricians or scientists with a strong statistical background and an M.S. or PhD in Fishery Sciences or a related field.
101.safetyConsiderations: Operation of the adult trap at LGR may occur during harsh weather (cold, snow, rain, lightning) and caution should be taken during those times. Also, during periods when many fish are being handled at the trap operations may be hectic and precautions should be taken to ensure the safety of technicians and to those around them. Floors and surface may be slick and appropriate footwear should be worn. Precautions should also be taken when anesthetizing, handling, and tagging adult salmonids to minimize potential mortality of captured individuals.
101.fieldScheduleNotes: Fish captured in the LGR adult fish trap MUST be processed daily each day that the trap gate is operated. Ideally, the trap is operated throughout the migration season. The fish ladder is generally dewatered in December and through Jan/Feb. IPTDS are generally operated year-round and maintenance may be needed at any time throughout the season.
101.budgetConsiderations: IPTDS are operated throughout the entire Snake River basin, and thus, travel to and maintenance of IPTDS sites may incur unforeseen costs. Equipment at the LGR adult trapping facility are extensive and operation and maintenance of the facility occurs throughout most of the year.
101.name: PIT tag Based Escapement Estimation Above Lower Granite Dam v1.0

105.backgroundRationale:
This protocol was developed to document status (current conditions) and trend (changes over time) monitoring for juvenile spring Chinook and steelhead in the Entiat River subbasin under the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP; BPA Project 2003-017).  The work described in this protocol is guided by the Upper Columbia Monitoring Strategy (UCMS, Hillman 2006), which outlines a monitoring strategy specific to the Upper Columbia Basin that was based on monitoring approaches adopted by the Independent Scientific Advisory Board of the Northwest Planning council (ISAB), Action Agencies/NOAA Fisheries, and the Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB). The sampling design for fish status and trend monitoring in the Entiat River subbasin is based on a Generalized Random-Tessellation Sampling design with an annual panel of up to 18 sites structured to distribute sampling effort in space (Stevens and Olsen 2004). These sites are co-located with the habitat monitoring annual panel sites proposed under the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP; BPA Project 2011-006). All fish monitoring data will be subjected to standard QA/QC processes and uploaded to PTAGIS.

This monitoring will result in the collection and analysis of systematic anadromous salmonid status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide population trends.  When coupled with habitat data, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies.

This protocol describes techniques used to capture, handle and PIT tag fish and includes Electro Fishing, Snorkeling, Angling and Dip-net/Seining as the major capture methods. The use of Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags to support status and trend and effectiveness monitoring for listed juvenile spring Chinook and steelhead in the Upper Columbia has increased significantly over the past 5 years as the technology associated with passive detection of tags in the tributary environment and the coverage afforded by instream PIT tag detection arrays has improved. Data from PIT-tagged juveniles can be used to monitor the response of fish to habitat restoration actions and the status and trend of populations through survival, growth and abundance.  PIT tag data also allows us to characterize the movement patterns of tagged fish, supporting estimations of residency time, migration timing, and habitat use if the detection infrastructure is sufficient.
objectives: Evaluate status and trends of juvenile spring Chinook and steelhead in the Entiat River subbasin in wadeable, perennial streams below natural impassible barriers within TRT population boundaries.
105.keyAssumptions:
1. The sampling frame is representative of the target populations of spring Chinook and steelhead in the Entiat River subbasin.

2. That the frame is outside the scope of influence of any habitat or hatchery or harvest actions and therefore is representative of natural variability of the populations.
105.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data is collected in the field on handheld Juniper Allegro data loggers.  Synchronized to a programmatic Access database. Data are QAQC'd before being disseminated publicly through PTAGIS.
105.qualityControlConsiderations:
Any target fish initially identified to be in poor health (i.e., injury, >20% descaling) shall be enumerated and released.
Follow permit requirements for fish handling.
105.reportingConsiderations: Data is uploaded to PTAGIS within 2 weeks of data collection.  All QAQC'd and derived data will be available through ISEMP's website, currently being updated.
105.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Equipment Cleaning and Calibration should be performed as stated in the owner's manuals.  Equipment decontamination follows Washington State guidelines.
105.rolesAndResponsibilities:
The Crew Lead is responsible for ensuring that data are collected following the protocol and that fish health is a priority at all times. The Crew Lead is also responsible for ensuring that all equipment is in working condition, assigning crew members to tasks best suited to their experience, training and skill level (e.g., tagging, operating the electrofisher), and ensuring that work is completed efficiently and effectively at all times.  The Crew Lead is responsible for reporting to the Crew Supervisor at the end of each sampling event any issues or problems that were encountered, and backing up data, ensuring permit compliance.

Crew members are responsible for understanding the protocol and implementing it to the fullest extent possible, maintaining required personal gear in good working condition, and performing their duties efficiently and effectively.
105.qualifications: All crew leads BSc or equivalent work experience in fisheries ecology or similar field.
105.trainingRequirements:
Crew lead or crew member operating the electrofisher must have successfully completed a recognized training course, for example, Smith-Root certification.

Crew leads and crew members must be up-to-date in First Aid/CPR.
105.safetyConsiderations:
Operate the electrofisher according to manufacturer, NOAA and other appropriate agency guidelines.

Electrofishing should be carried out in water no greater than one meter in depth.

Use care in entering/exiting stream, so not to break banks down.
105.fieldScheduleNotes: Field sampling is scheduled for the summer low-flow season, generally from July through September, with one crew of 3 personnel (crew lead plus two crew members), 2 hitches, 4 days each, 2 sites per day, 10 hour day.  Sites are sampled based on when flow is low enough to sample instream with electrofisher and are grouped within a day/hitch to reduce driving distance.
105.budgetConsiderations: Need at least 2 electrofishers on hand, one as back-up, sites that are close together should be sampled on same day/consecutive days to reduce travel time/cost.  Camping in the field can help reduce travel time and allow efficient sampling of remote sites.

107.backgroundRationale:
Efforts to recover threatened and endangered species often rely on models to identify management strategies that will improve the status of at-risk populations (Good et al., 2007; Sweka and Wainwright, 2014). Fundamental to this work is the task of building models that are structurally and/or numerically consistent with the scales of relevant biological processes and management actions (Green et al., 2005). For species like Pacific salmon and steelhead (Oncorhynchus spp.), this is especially challenging given that they respond to factors operating at widely varying spatial and temporal scales. For example, the foraging success, growth, and survival of individuals can be influenced by conditions within small (10-100 m2) patches of stream habitat (e.g., Rosenfeld and Taylor, 2009), yet a river’s overall capacity to produce juvenile fish may be set by a habitat limitation for another life stage that is governed by broader-scale geomorphic controls (e.g., spawning, Buffington et al., 2004; Palm et al., 2007). Similarly, global climatic phenomena (e.g., El Niño Southern Oscillation) can affect the survival of salmon during marine life stages (e.g., Sharma et al., 2013) to an extent that makes it difficult to detect the effects of other factors (e.g., Schaller et al., 2013). Accordingly, there is a great need for modelling approaches that can accurately depict complex life histories and simultaneously maximize the realism of species–environment relationships for life stages targeted by management/restoration.

Despite a rich history of life-cycle model (LCM) applications to salmon recovery-related questions (see Good et al., 2007 for a recent review), previous attempts to link habitat restoration scenarios with future population performance have met with limited success. For example, studies have quantified population responses to hypothetical survival increases assumed to be achievable through habitat restoration, but without explicit consideration of current conditions and/or restoration feasibility (e.g., Kareiva et al., 2000). More recent assessments have integrated habitat–survival relationships and basin-specific habitat information into modelling (Honea et al., 2009; McHugh et al., 2004; Scheuerell et al., 2006), assessed restoration potential based on relationships between watershed condition and in-stream habitat metrics (Bartz et al., 2006; Jorgensen et al., 2009; Sharma et al., 2005), and/or increased the spatial resolution of LCMs (Scheuerell et al., 2006). The realism of LCMs has thus improved greatly, yet these tools continue to inform restoration practice at a coarse level of resolution only (e.g., current condition vs. historic potential) and in the absence of mechanistic insight on fish–habitat associations. Thus, approaches that integrate LCMs with reach-level habitat observations and restoration plans are needed.
objectives: Develop Life Cycle Models that can be used to support decision making for management actions targeting ESA listed salmonids in the Columbia River Basin.
107.keyAssumptions:
Beverton-Holt stock recruitment relationship is the correct freshwater productivity relationship for salmonids.

Model consumes derived estimates and each of those estimates are accompanied by own suite of assumptions e.g., rotary screw trap estimates of juvenile abundance.

Relationship between fish productivity is known and relative to metrics of habitat quality and quantity
107.dataHandlingConsiderations: We use a GIT repository tool called BitBucket, which has a companion desktop tool called SourceTree
107.reportingConsiderations: tabular and graphic output of population growth rate over time
107.name: Duwamish Test Design ISEMP Life Cycle Models v1.0

113.backgroundRationale:
In-stream PIT tag Detection Systems (IPTDS) have been installed across the Columbia River Basin for the purpose of estimating juvenile and adult abundance, survival, and distribution. For most applications individual tag detections have limited value without accompanying information about detection probability (i.e., fraction of PIT tags that may have transited an array without detection). This protocol describes how standard diagnostic data can be reported and utilized to support estimates of detection probability.

For this protocol, we assume that IPTDS are intended to operate in a temporally continuous manner for a given time period (i.e., 365 days/year; during the spawning migration, etc.). We also assume that the analysis of interrogation data requires the ability to estimate detection probabilities. Given these assumptions it is critical that site diagnostic and detection data can be accessed in near-real-time. In other words, periods of in-operation resulting from equipment or power failures are assumed to be detrimental.

Although IPTDS are typically installed to address the information needs of a specific project, interrogation data from IPTDS are often leveraged in other forums or designs. In order for IPTDS interrogation data to be useful for meta-analyses, users without specific familiarity with a given IPTDS must be able to assess the statistical reliability of the interrogation data. IPTDS site metadata standards are enforced by IPTDS registration as a “small-scale site” in the PIT Tag Information System (PTAGIS; www.ptagis.org). PTAGIS displays IPTDS site maps, summarizes IPTDS infrastructure, and allows for “event log” entries that describe system failures and alert data consumers to potential gaps in information resulting from site failure or routine periods of in-operation. The site maps displayed in PTAGIS can be used to determine whether detection data are sufficient to meet the assumptions of commonly-used statistical analyses.

This protocol also requires the use of routine diagnostic and interrogation file downloads from a given IPTDS. We recommend a daily download interval, which typically requires the use of a cellular or satellite modem. Routine download and review of diagnostic and interrogation data provides advanced warning of impending system failure, thus reducing repair costs, and reduces the potential for lost data resulting from system failure. Analyzing and interpreting diagnostic data from IPTDS system components can be challenging. We recommend using a commercially available service that automates data downloads, performs routine data summaries, and provides automated email or text alerts when diagnostic data indicate potential system failures (e.g., the Biomark, Inc. “Data Manager” service).
objectives: Describe standard infrastructure, data collection, and data management to generate detection data with known detection probability.
Support assessment of abundance, movements and timing of fish emigration and immigration and origin
Ensure operation of the array and upload of Data for operation data
113.keyAssumptions: This protocol describes a standard for IPTDS infrastructure and data management, and therefore is not accompanied by assumptions. However the use of IPTDS interrogation data is subject to the assumptions of whatever statistical framework is employed.
113.dataHandlingConsiderations: This protocol relies on automated parsing of IPTDS interrogation and diagnostic data to create PTAGIS interrogation upload files and user alerts generated when diagnostic data indicate that one or more IPTDS components is not operating within specification. In order to generate reliable data, it is critical that site diagnostics and interrogation data are downloaded on a continuous and routine basis; preferably daily. It is often most cost-effective to utilize cellular, satellite, or Ethernet modems to download data, particularly for IPTDS in remote locations. Data is uploaded into PTAGIS (http://www.ptagis.org/)
113.qualityControlConsiderations: We strongly recommend the use of commercially available software (e.g., Biomark, Inc. "Data Manager") to manage IPTDS interrogation and diagnostic data. The process of converting standard site downloads into PTAGIS upload files is reasonably straightforward, but can be time consuming; doing so also introduces the potential for human error. Additionally, site diagnostic data are voluminous and may be difficult to interpret. The commercially available service referenced here automates the reduction and display of these data in a user-friendly format and generates email alerts when diagnostic data indicate potential system failure. Data is recorded and uploaded, if there is a misread the data does not get uploaded (QA/QC done by BioMark)
113.reportingConsiderations: It is crucial that IPTDS operators consistently maintain their site metadata in PTAGIS. Changes in site "architecture" (i.e., location of antennas within the stream channel), infrastructure, and periods of system failure all must be known to analyze interrogation data. Similarly, timely (e.g., daily) interrogation data uploads to PTAGIS are recommended.
113.rolesAndResponsibilities: We strongly recommend that one individual is identified to be the primary "site steward" for a given IPTDS. A backup site steward should be identified for periods when the primary steward is unavailable. The site steward is responsible for reviewing interrogation and diagnostic data on a daily basis to ensure that the IPTDS is functioning properly.
113.qualifications: Data management requires strong computer skills including the ability to manipulate complex spreadsheets and/or simple databases. IPTDS maintenance requires: advanced electrical skills; a strong understanding of low-frequency radio frequency identification theory and common components; a strong understanding of common communications protocols such as TCP/IP, terminal, and terminal emulators; familiarity with commonly used power sources such as alternating current (grid power) and direct current (thermoelectric generators and solar); understanding of AC/DC conversion; and attention to detail.
113.safetyConsiderations: Some IPTDS components generate extremely high voltages/amperages. Site stewards will commonly find themselves working in remote locations in inclement weather. Where possible, we strongly recommend that a minimum of two individuals conduct maintenance activities.
113.fieldScheduleNotes: We recommend budgeting labor and travel for one routine maintenance visit per year and one emergency visit every other year. If communication with the site cannot be conducted remotely (e.g., using a satellite or cellular modem), we strongly recommend daily site visits to download interrogation and diagnostic data.
113.budgetConsiderations: As a rule of thumb, we recommend budgeting replacement parts at 5% of total infrastructure costs per year. Note that catastrophic failures resulting from downed trees or flood conditions are not uncommon and may result in repair costs that approach complete replacement.
113.name: In-Stream PIT tag Detection System (IPTDS) Data Standards

116.backgroundRationale:
The ISEMP is a collaborative effort to 1) design, test, implement and evaluate Status and Trends Monitoring for salmon and steelhead populations and their habitat and 2) conduct watershed-scale Effectiveness Monitoring for management actions impacting salmon and steelhead populations and habitat in the Interior Columbia River Basin. ISEMP takes a pilot-project approach to the research and development of monitoring by implementing experimental programs in several major subbasins of the Interior Columbia.

To achieve these goals, population-specific and aggregate estimates of juvenile abundance and survival are necessary. These metrics will be estimated using information from the recapture of juveniles that are PIT tagged during remote tagging surveys or at rotary screw traps. Recapture data for tagged individuals will be obtained interrogations at Instream PIT Tag Detection Systems (IPTDS) and from recapture at rotary screw traps. ISEMP operated rotary screw traps in the South Fork Salmon and Lemhi rivers to estimate juvenile abundance and survival in those sub-basins.

The multiple locations and variable scale nature of this goal requires the standardization of protocols and sampling designs that are statistically valid and powerful. This protocol aims to 1) provide standardization of trapping and fish handling methods among rotary screw traps operated by ISEMP, and 2) provide a brief description of trap efficiency and juvenile abundance estimation methods using rotary screw traps.

This monitoring protocol is a component of the overall ISEMP, and while it stands alone as an important contribution to the management of anadromous salmonids and their habitat, it also plays a key role within ISEMP as it is built on a standardized format following Oakley et al. (2003) that all of the ISEMP protocols adhere to. Downstream migrant trapping of juvenile salmonids can be a valuable tool to estimate abundance, production, size, survival, migration timing and behavior (Volkhardt et al. 2007). Of significance to status, trend and effectiveness monitoring programs, simple mark-recapture methods can be used with downstream migrant traps to estimate total freshwater production, and enable the estimation of survival (and mortality) between life stages (e.g., egg-to-smolt).
objectives: Provide standardization of trapping and fish handling protocols among rotary screw traps operated by ISEMP in the South Fork Salmon and Lemhi rivers
Indirectly, estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead survival (egg-to-smolt)
Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead emigration abundance at ISEMP rotary screw traps
Estimate trap efficiency for juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead at ISEMP rotary screw traps
116.keyAssumptions:
Regarding efficiency estimates:

  1. Rotary screw traps are function properly (when not attended) on intended trapping days
  2. Mortality of marked and unmarked individuals is equal
  3. Marked individuals retain their marks (tags) and all tags are detected upon recapture
  4. Marked individuals are captured at the same rate as unmarked individuals (no trap avoidance or happiness)
  5. Marked individuals mix randomly among unmarked individuals
  6. Marked individuals are representative of the entire target population for which abundance and survival will be estimated

Moreover, we assume that trap efficiency estimates accurately reflect the true proportion of the captured emigrating population.
116.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are recorded on standardized data forms on waterproof paper and entered on a laptop computer at the field site. PIT tag files are stored in P3 and later uploaded to PTAGIS.P3, also known as PITTag3, is a data entry, edit, and validation tool developed expressly to facilitate the collection of PIT tag mark/recapture data in the Columbia/Snake river basins. P3 can be downloaded at: http://www.ptagis.org/software/softwaredetails/p3
116.qualityControlConsiderations: Electronic data forms and P3 require that all necessary data fields are completed. Data are reviewed daily and checked for accuracy. Any suspected errors are reviewed with the crew members who entered the data prior to make any changes to data prior to upload to PTAGIS. Further, PTAGIS provides its own data review and error checking process.
116.reportingConsiderations: Individual biological data and PIT tag data for tagged juveniles (and subsequent detection data) are stored and publicly available at PTAGIS (www.ptagis.org). Moreover, individual biological and count data are stored in a central database located on a QCI server housed in Boise, ID. Data are synthesized and summarized in annual reports to the Bonneville Power Administration.
116.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: The screw trap cone must be cleaned and cleared of debris, periodically. Special attention must be given to the screw trap cone and equipment during high and increasing river flows. Large debris entering the cone may stop the cone from turning and/or damage the structure which may result in fish mortality. Screw trap pontoons, trap boxes, and cone, etc. must periodically be examined for damage and maintenance completed as needed. The trap box livewell and revolving debris drum must also be cleared regularly to ensure optimal conditions for captured fish.
116.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Crew leaders hire field technicians for daily operation of rotary screw traps. Crew leaders also assign scheduling of technicians, provide training to technicians, ensure that technicians abide by established protocols, provide data QA/QC, analyze data, produce reports, and assist at needed at field sites.

Technicians are tasked with data collection at the field site including fish identification, enumerating fish to species, collecting lengths and weights, recording data on data forms and on a field laptop, providing trap maintenance, and PIT tagging juvenile salmonids of adequate size.
116.qualifications: Crew leaders are typically fisheries biologists and should have adequate leadership skills and, ideally, prior experience operating and managing rotary screw traps. Crew leaders are in charge of hiring and reviewing qualifications of potential technicians. Technicians should be organized and have excellent data recording skills as well as be able to tolerate long hours in potentially harsh conditions.
116.trainingRequirements: Juvenile fish identification skills are necessary for all personnel. See Pollard et al. 1997 for reference. Crew should also exhibit mechanical aptitude for installation of rotary screw traps and modification of screw trap rigging as necessary.
116.safetyConsiderations:
Individuals must exercise extreme caution when operating rotary screw traps. Personal flotation devices should be used when getting to rotary screw traps and when operating on the rotary screw trap. Operations may occur in harsh weather (snow, hail, rain, lightning) and caution should be taken during those times.

Precautions should also be taken when anesthetizing, handling, and PIT tagging juvenile salmonids to minimize potential mortality of captured individuals.
116.fieldScheduleNotes: Rotary screw traps must be attended to and fish processed daily during the trapping season. Rotary screw traps are generally installed instream in spring when instream conditions allow (e.g., snow has melted adequately, ice is gone, site location is accessible). Rotary screw trap should be closely monitored during high flows are during/after heavy rain events and should be removed if debris is present in the river or if flows are too high for safe operation. Trap is generally removed in late fall when ice begins appearing in river.
116.budgetConsiderations: Rotary screw traps are expensive and should be closely monitored (especially during high flows) to minimize damage to the trap. Maintenance can be difficult and expensive. Operation of the trap must occur daily during the trapping season, and thus, require a lot of staff time.
116.name: Duwamish Test Design ISEMP Cooperator Rotary Screw Trap Operation v1.0

These metrics will be estimated using information from the recapture of juveniles that are PIT tagged during remote tagging surveys or at rotary screw traps. Recapture data for tagged individuals will be obtained interrogations at Instream PIT Tag Detection Systems (IPTDS) and from recapture at rotary screw traps. ISEMP operated rotary screw traps in the South Fork Salmon and Lemhi rivers to estimate juvenile abundance and survival in those sub-basins.

The multiple locations and variable scale nature of this goal requires the standardization of protocols and sampling designs that are statistically valid and powerful. This protocol aims to 1) provide standardization of trapping and fish handling methods among rotary screw traps operated by ISEMP, and 2) provide a brief description of trap efficiency and juvenile abundance estimation methods using rotary screw traps.

This monitoring protocol is a component of the overall ISEMP, and while it stands alone as an important contribution to the management of anadromous salmonids and their habitat, it also plays a key role within ISEMP as it is built on a standardized format following Oakley et al. (2003) that all of the ISEMP protocols adhere to. Downstream migrant trapping of juvenile salmonids can be a valuable tool to estimate abundance, production, size, survival, migration timing and behavior (Volkhardt et al. 2007). Of significance to status, trend and effectiveness monitoring programs, simple mark-recapture methods can be used with downstream migrant traps to estimate total freshwater production, and enable the estimation of survival (and mortality) between life stages (e.g., egg-to-smolt).
objectives: Provide standardization of trapping and fish handling protocols among rotary screw traps operated by ISEMP in the South Fork Salmon and Lemhi rivers
Indirectly, estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead survival (egg-to-smolt)
Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead emigration abundance at ISEMP rotary screw traps
Estimate trap efficiency for juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead at ISEMP rotary screw traps
118.keyAssumptions:
Regarding efficiency estimates:

  1. Rotary screw traps are function properly (when not attended) on intended trapping days
  2. Mortality of marked and unmarked individuals is equal
  3. Marked individuals retain their marks (tags) and all tags are detected upon recapture
  4. Marked individuals are captured at the same rate as unmarked individuals (no trap avoidance or happiness)
  5. Marked individuals mix randomly among unmarked individuals
  6. Marked individuals are representative of the entire target population for which abundance and survival will be estimated

Moreover, we assume that trap efficiency estimates accurately reflect the true proportion of the captured emigrating population.
118.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are recorded on standardized data forms on waterproof paper and entered on a laptop computer at the field site. PIT tag files are stored in P3 and later uploaded to PTAGIS.P3, also known as PITTag3, is a data entry, edit, and validation tool developed expressly to facilitate the collection of PIT tag mark/recapture data in the Columbia/Snake river basins. P3 can be downloaded at: http://www.ptagis.org/software/softwaredetails/p3
118.qualityControlConsiderations: Electronic data forms and P3 require that all necessary data fields are completed. Data are reviewed daily and checked for accuracy. Any suspected errors are reviewed with the crew members who entered the data prior to make any changes to data prior to upload to PTAGIS. Further, PTAGIS provides its own data review and error checking process.
118.reportingConsiderations: Individual biological data and PIT tag data for tagged juveniles (and subsequent detection data) are stored and publicly available at PTAGIS (www.ptagis.org). Moreover, individual biological and count data are stored in a central database located on a QCI server housed in Boise, ID. Data are synthesized and summarized in annual reports to the Bonneville Power Administration.
118.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: The screw trap cone must be cleaned and cleared of debris, periodically. Special attention must be given to the screw trap cone and equipment during high and increasing river flows. Large debris entering the cone may stop the cone from turning and/or damage the structure which may result in fish mortality. Screw trap pontoons, trap boxes, and cone, etc. must periodically be examined for damage and maintenance completed as needed. The trap box livewell and revolving debris drum must also be cleared regularly to ensure optimal conditions for captured fish.
118.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Crew leaders hire field technicians for daily operation of rotary screw traps. Crew leaders also assign scheduling of technicians, provide training to technicians, ensure that technicians abide by established protocols, provide data QA/QC, analyze data, produce reports, and assist at needed at field sites.

Technicians are tasked with data collection at the field site including fish identification, enumerating fish to species, collecting lengths and weights, recording data on data forms and on a field laptop, providing trap maintenance, and PIT tagging juvenile salmonids of adequate size.
118.qualifications: Crew leaders are typically fisheries biologists and should have adequate leadership skills and, ideally, prior experience operating and managing rotary screw traps. Crew leaders are in charge of hiring and reviewing qualifications of potential technicians. Technicians should be organized and have excellent data recording skills as well as be able to tolerate long hours in potentially harsh conditions.
118.trainingRequirements: Juvenile fish identification skills are necessary for all personnel. See Pollard et al. 1997 for reference. Crew should also exhibit mechanical aptitude for installation of rotary screw traps and modification of screw trap rigging as necessary.
118.safetyConsiderations:
Individuals must exercise extreme caution when operating rotary screw traps. Personal flotation devices should be used when getting to rotary screw traps and when operating on the rotary screw trap. Operations may occur in harsh weather (snow, hail, rain, lightning) and caution should be taken during those times.

Precautions should also be taken when anesthetizing, handling, and PIT tagging juvenile salmonids to minimize potential mortality of captured individuals.
118.fieldScheduleNotes: Rotary screw traps must be attended to and fish processed daily during the trapping season. Rotary screw traps are generally installed instream in spring when instream conditions allow (e.g., snow has melted adequately, ice is gone, site location is accessible). Rotary screw trap should be closely monitored during high flows are during/after heavy rain events and should be removed if debris is present in the river or if flows are too high for safe operation. Trap is generally removed in late fall when ice begins appearing in river.
118.budgetConsiderations: Rotary screw traps are expensive and should be closely monitored (especially during high flows) to minimize damage to the trap. Maintenance can be difficult and expensive. Operation of the trap must occur daily during the trapping season, and thus, require a lot of staff time.
118.name: Operation Monitor Salmon ISEMP Cooperator Rotary Screw Trap Operation v1.0

122.backgroundRationale:
The Bridge Creek watershed is used by a by a run of Mid-Columbia steelhead that are part of the ecologically distinct and ESA (Endangered Species Act) “threatened” Lower John Day population. It is also used intermittently by Mid-Columbia Chinook salmon, another "threatened" population. Bridge Creek was listed as one of 11 tributary Major Spawning Areas (MaSAs) critical to the recovery of the Lower John Day steelhead Major Population Group (MPG), and was identified as having high restoration potential. Many areas along Bridge Creek have historically experienced high levels of incision, degradation, and high stream temperatures making them inhospitable to salmon populations.

Floodplain connectivity and riparian structure were listed as a high restoration priority for the lower valley on Bridge Creek. Re-establishing both surface and groundwater connections between the stream and floodplain increases the amount and quality of fish habitat. Since 2009, beaver dam analogs (BDAs) have been installed in the area, encouraging beaver migration into the area and beaver dam formation. The damming of Bridge Creek has resulted in soil aggradation and floodplain inundation. Floodplain inundation promotes groundwater recharge and water table rise, which in turn support perennial streamflow, cooler water temperatures (due to groundwater upwelling), and riparian vegetation growth. Riparian vegetation provides shade and organic inputs to the stream ecosystem (e.g., prey, woody debris, leaf litter) which improves fish habitat quality. In addition, riparian vegetation is also critical for supporting and maintaining stable beaver colonies, which are an important part of the Bridge Creek restoration strategy. Finally, connected floodplains can also directly provide important off-channel refuge for fish during high flows, expand rearing areas, and increase foraging opportunities. 

This protocol presents a framework by which to monitor the effectiveness of the Bridge Creek restoration efforts in transforming incised stream networks into healthy, functioning riparian ecosystems. It outlines which vegetative and landscape factors should be measured to determine riparian health. It will also address the restoration methods specific to Bridge Creek, with variables that take into account the impact of BDAs and beaver introduction on floodplain vegetation and landscape structure. By repeating this survey protocol over multiple years, temporal trends in vegetation and landscape may be observed. The survey methods implemented in this protocol are supported by the methodologies outlined in two other government-agency led reports: the multiple indicator monitoring of stream channels and streamside vegetation (MIM 2011), and the PACFISH/INFISH effectiveness monitoring program for sampling vegetation in streams and riparian areas (PIBO-EM 2008). These two protocols helped guide us in choosing important riparian indicators to measure and allows us to place this effectiveness monitoring protocol in the context of other monitoring studies.
objectives: Species-level vegetation surveys will help describe the effects of beaver dams and beaver browse on floodplain vegetation composition, abundance, and biodiversity.
Monitoring will also track beaver utilization of riparian vegetation.
Observations in riparian cross sections (transects) will describe how these variables change with increasing distance from the main channel, and will help track landscape-level response.
122.name: Duwamish Test Design Effectiveness Monitoring of Floodplain Vegetation in Response to Beaver Dam Analogs v1.0
