125.backgroundRationale: CHaMP is designed as a Columbia River basin-wide habitat status and trends monitoring program built around a single protocol with a programmatic approach to data collection and management (RM&E Workgroup 2010). CHaMP will result in the collection and analysis of systematic habitat status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide habitat conditions. When coupled with biological response indicators, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies. This program will be integrated with ongoing Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Program (PNAMP) recovery planning efforts and will be part of the collaborative process across Columbia Basin fish management agencies and tribes and other state and federal agencies that are monitoring anadromous salmonids and/or their habitat. The implementation of CHaMP will characterize stream responses to watershed restoration and/or management actions in at least one population within each steelhead and spring Chinook Major Population Group (MPG) which have, or will have, “fish-in” and “fish-out” monitoring (identified in RPA 50.6), thereby meeting the requirements of RPA 56.3, RPA 57, and RPA 3. CHaMP was designed to deliver trends in habitat indicators and requires that monitoring occurs for three cycles of a sampling panel (see section 1.6), at least 9 years.
objectives: The stream habitat data will be applied in conjunction with salmonid growth, survival, abundance and productivity data to estimate fish-habitat relationships across the Upper Columbia River Basin area

To generate standardized status and trend and effectiveness monitoring data for salmonid habitat in important Major Population Groups and spaitally diverse watersheds of the Columbia River Basin area.

To assess the quantity and quality of stream habitat for salmonids in wadeable, perennial streams below natural impassible barriers within Technical Recovery Team population boundaries across the UCRB
125.keyAssumptions: The protocol is structured around a general understanding of the link between habitat attributes and how they directly relate to the specific life history requirements of the salmonid fishes managed under the 2008 BiOp. These fish are likely not only responding to watershed and reach conditions but also to the conditions of individual channel units within reaches. Recognizing the importance of how interactions at the channel unit scale affect fish performance has led to an increased emphasis on the quantification of this important scale of fish habitat in the CHaMP protocol. We adopted the Hawkins et al. (1993) hierarchical classification scheme that allows for summarization of information across multiple scales. This preserves the ability to summarize information at the site scale as commonly practiced in major fish habitat monitoring programs throughout the Pacific Northwest as well as at the smaller channel-unit and topographical feature scales. The protocol employs spatially continuous sampling strategies using well-established surveying techniques to conduct precise topographic surveys from which digital elevation models (DEMs) can be produced. These topographic surveys are augmented by auxiliary data (e.g., channel classification, fish cover, substrate composition, distribution and embeddedness, large woody debris (LWD), solar input and water temperature, stream discharge, water chemistry, riparian structure, and site-level human influence) that help to characterize aspects of channel units that influence site-scale fish production potential. The CHaMP protocol draws together methods from many existing protocols as well as novel approaches to collecting and analyzing channel geomorphological data. The protocol is designed to collect data that fits within a geomorphological hierarchy spanning spatial scales ranging from within-unit topographical features to channel units to geomorphic to watershed and subbasin scales.
125.dataHandlingConsiderations: The CHaMP data management plan is integral to ensuring successful capture, quality assurance, and archiving of CHaMP field data along with the derivation and reporting of site-level metrics.  The data system will be comprised of field data capture tools and a centralized database with an online interface.  The online interface will support pre-season site evaluations, tracking project metadata, uploading field data, quality assurance procedures, and reporting derived metrics.  Under this plan, data will initially be captured on handheld field computers and then uploaded to the online database when internet connectivity is available.  A standard set of field data capture devices will be provided which will include data entry applications for the topographic and auxiliary habitat surveys.  This two-part system allows remote capture of data and centralized management of metadata, field measurements, and derived metrics.  Collectively, these tools support CHaMP’s data documentation, data capture, data quality, information archiving, standard metric calculation, and project reporting needs. Topographic survey data and auxiliary data will be captured using separate data logger applications.  Auxiliary data (wood loading, substrate composition, etc.) will be capture by a single crew member using a handheld field computer. The topography survey will create a raw topographic point file (x, y, z data) from which several geo-rectified products will be developed using survey (Leica Geo Office) and Arc GIS 10 software.  A triangular irregular network (TIN) and digital elevation model (DEM) will be created as the base topographic products from the survey.
125.qualityControlConsiderations:
Data quality assurance review will be conducted on a daily basis by crew members and on a weekly basis by the crew supervisor.  The quality assurance review will test for completeness, outliers in numeric data, and outliers in basic summary metrics.  At the end of each day, the crew member will be prompted to verify the number of channel units, total wood pieces, and number of drift samples.  Additionally, the crew will be prompted to review any values recorded as a missing value.  Next the crew will view and verify any numeric outliers. Finally, a short series of graphs will be presented to allow the crew to verify graphical data against their mental image of the site.  At the end of each week, the crew supervisor will perform a similar audit of the data. 
Data quality assurance for the topographic survey data will take place at four checkpoints within the flow of data from origination on the total station to data storage and web availability.  These checkpoints will reduce the likelihood of data errors compounding throughout data processing.  The four checkpoints are:
1.	Data origination (Total station)
2.	End of day data review (Total station/Data logger)
3.	End of week data processing and review (Laptop)
4.	Centralized database checks (CHaMP data system)
The crew lead is responsible for creation and submission of the original point file, a lines file (breaklines), a clean TIN, and a quality assurance report (table in geodatabase).  These should be produced within one week of initial data collection.
125.reportingConsiderations: Site-level metrics will be generated from data submitted to the CHaMP website.  These metrics will be presented in graphical and map format for all sites.  At the end of each field season, crew supervisors will review raw measurements and derived metrics for data completeness, numeric outliers, and ecologic sensibility.  Crew supervisors will be presented a series for graphs through the CHaMP website and asked to verify data quality.
125.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Total station and other equipment will be re-calibrated on an annual basis or more frequently as needed.
125.rolesAndResponsibilities:
1) The survey crew lays out the site, with two crew members monumenting the bottom of site and working upstream to the top placing transect flagging. The third crew member establishes monuments, benchmarks, control points, and potential survey set-up locations.
2) Once a site has been laid out, two crew members begin surveying the site. A site survey captures channel unit perimeters, maximum pool depths and crested depth, thalweg profile, channel topography, and breaklines establishing the bank and extent of the survey reaching the first floodplain or other elevations beyond the bankfull.
3) The third crew member identifies and flags channel units and collects channel unit-level measurements, including LWD counts, fish cover estimates, and ocular estimates of substrates. Subsurface fines and pebble count measurements are collected in a subset of channel units.
4) The third crew member collects site-level metrics, including drawing the site map, conducting the water quality measurements, taking site and solar pathfinder photos, recording human influences, making riparian estimates, and taking drift net samples.
5) Everyone collects flags once the survey is completed.
125.qualifications: Prospective crew members will ideally have a background in biology, preferably in relation to fish, familiarity with GIS, basics of land surveying (e.g., using a total station), and experience living and working in the outdoors. Candidates must be able to work well with others, usually in a crew of 3-6, while enduring long and sometimes arduous days. Camping for multiple days and packing heavy loads of equipment in and out of sites is required periodically. Previous wilderness first aid knowledge is a plus, but not required.
125.trainingRequirements: All crew leaders and members will attend a 10 day pre-season training session. Crew will learn the theoretical background for the CHaMP protocol, proper use and maintenance of all field equipment, and procedures for data management.
125.safetyConsiderations: Each data collection organization will define safety constraints for accessing sites (e.g. sites must be less than 5 trail miles from a trail head and less than 1/2 mile from a trail or road). Sites will be rejected for sampling if the site falls outside these safety constraints.
125.fieldScheduleNotes:
Pre-Season (April-June 15th)	Document project, statistical design, and site evaluation metadata.

Field-Season (June 15-Sept 30th)	Daily data capture and quality assurance review of topographic and auxiliary data. Complete weekly quality assurance procedures and generated TIN file for each site. Perform weekly uploads of datasets to CHaMP website.

Post-Season (Oct 1- Oct 30th)	Ensure datasets are complete. Perform quality assurance on completed datasets and derived site-level metrics.
125.budgetConsiderations:
This protocol requires a wide range of equipment. One of the more expensive devices is the topographic surveying instrument required to survey each site. After some field trials, the CHaMP team settled on a Nikon Total Station:
http://www.nikon.com/about/technology/life/others/surveying/index.htm
125.name: Basin Creek Utah Scientific Protocol for Salmonid Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) v1.0

The protocol employs spatially continuous sampling strategies using well-established surveying techniques to conduct precise topographic surveys from which digital elevation models (DEMs) can be produced. These topographic surveys are augmented by auxiliary data (e.g., channel classification, fish cover, substrate composition, distribution and embeddedness, large woody debris (LWD), solar input and water temperature, stream discharge, water chemistry, riparian structure, and site-level human influence) that help to characterize aspects of channel units that influence site-scale fish production potential. The CHaMP protocol draws together methods from many existing protocols as well as novel approaches to collecting and analyzing channel geomorphological data. The protocol is designed to collect data that fits within a geomorphological hierarchy spanning spatial scales ranging from within-unit topographical features to channel units to geomorphic to watershed and subbasin scales.
126.dataHandlingConsiderations: The CHaMP data management plan is integral to ensuring successful capture, quality assurance, and archiving of CHaMP field data along with the derivation and reporting of site-level metrics.  The data system will be comprised of field data capture tools and a centralized database with an online interface.  The online interface will support pre-season site evaluations, tracking project metadata, uploading field data, quality assurance procedures, and reporting derived metrics.  Under this plan, data will initially be captured on handheld field computers and then uploaded to the online database when internet connectivity is available.  A standard set of field data capture devices will be provided which will include data entry applications for the topographic and auxiliary habitat surveys.  This two-part system allows remote capture of data and centralized management of metadata, field measurements, and derived metrics.  Collectively, these tools support CHaMP’s data documentation, data capture, data quality, information archiving, standard metric calculation, and project reporting needs. Topographic survey data and auxiliary data will be captured using separate data logger applications.  Auxiliary data (wood loading, substrate composition, etc.) will be capture by a single crew member using a handheld field computer. The topography survey will create a raw topographic point file (x, y, z data) from which several geo-rectified products will be developed using survey (Leica Geo Office) and Arc GIS 10 software.  A triangular irregular network (TIN) and digital elevation model (DEM) will be created as the base topographic products from the survey.
126.qualityControlConsiderations:
Data quality assurance review will be conducted on a daily basis by crew members and on a weekly basis by the crew supervisor.  The quality assurance review will test for completeness, outliers in numeric data, and outliers in basic summary metrics.  At the end of each day, the crew member will be prompted to verify the number of channel units, total wood pieces, and number of drift samples.  Additionally, the crew will be prompted to review any values recorded as a missing value.  Next the crew will view and verify any numeric outliers. Finally, a short series of graphs will be presented to allow the crew to verify graphical data against their mental image of the site.  At the end of each week, the crew supervisor will perform a similar audit of the data. 
Data quality assurance for the topographic survey data will take place at four checkpoints within the flow of data from origination on the total station to data storage and web availability.  These checkpoints will reduce the likelihood of data errors compounding throughout data processing.  The four checkpoints are:
1.	Data origination (Total station)
2.	End of day data review (Total station/Data logger)
3.	End of week data processing and review (Laptop)
4.	Centralized database checks (CHaMP data system)
The crew lead is responsible for creation and submission of the original point file, a lines file (breaklines), a clean TIN, and a quality assurance report (table in geodatabase).  These should be produced within one week of initial data collection.
126.reportingConsiderations: Site-level metrics will be generated from data submitted to the CHaMP website.  These metrics will be presented in graphical and map format for all sites.  At the end of each field season, crew supervisors will review raw measurements and derived metrics for data completeness, numeric outliers, and ecologic sensibility.  Crew supervisors will be presented a series for graphs through the CHaMP website and asked to verify data quality.
126.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Total station and other equipment will be re-calibrated on an annual basis or more frequently as needed.
126.rolesAndResponsibilities:
1) The survey crew lays out the site, with two crew members monumenting the bottom of site and working upstream to the top placing transect flagging. The third crew member establishes monuments, benchmarks, control points, and potential survey set-up locations.
2) Once a site has been laid out, two crew members begin surveying the site. A site survey captures channel unit perimeters, maximum pool depths and crested depth, thalweg profile, channel topography, and breaklines establishing the bank and extent of the survey reaching the first floodplain or other elevations beyond the bankfull.
3) The third crew member identifies and flags channel units and collects channel unit-level measurements, including LWD counts, fish cover estimates, and ocular estimates of substrates. Subsurface fines and pebble count measurements are collected in a subset of channel units.
4) The third crew member collects site-level metrics, including drawing the site map, conducting the water quality measurements, taking site and solar pathfinder photos, recording human influences, making riparian estimates, and taking drift net samples.
5) Everyone collects flags once the survey is completed.
126.qualifications: Prospective crew members will ideally have a background in biology, preferably in relation to fish, familiarity with GIS, basics of land surveying (e.g., using a total station), and experience living and working in the outdoors. Candidates must be able to work well with others, usually in a crew of 3-6, while enduring long and sometimes arduous days. Camping for multiple days and packing heavy loads of equipment in and out of sites is required periodically. Previous wilderness first aid knowledge is a plus, but not required.
126.trainingRequirements: All crew leaders and members will attend a 10 day pre-season training session. Crew will learn the theoretical background for the CHaMP protocol, proper use and maintenance of all field equipment, and procedures for data management.
126.safetyConsiderations: Each data collection organization will define safety constraints for accessing sites (e.g. sites must be less than 5 trail miles from a trail head and less than 1/2 mile from a trail or road). Sites will be rejected for sampling if the site falls outside these safety constraints.
126.fieldScheduleNotes:
Pre-Season (April-June 15th)	Document project, statistical design, and site evaluation metadata.

Field-Season (June 15-Sept 30th)	Daily data capture and quality assurance review of topographic and auxiliary data. Complete weekly quality assurance procedures and generated TIN file for each site. Perform weekly uploads of datasets to CHaMP website.

Post-Season (Oct 1- Oct 30th)	Ensure datasets are complete. Perform quality assurance on completed datasets and derived site-level metrics.
126.budgetConsiderations:
This protocol requires a wide range of equipment. One of the more expensive devices is the topographic surveying instrument required to survey each site. After some field trials, the CHaMP team settled on a Nikon Total Station:
http://www.nikon.com/about/technology/life/others/surveying/index.htm

2) Once a site has been laid out, two crew members begin surveying the site. A site survey captures channel unit perimeters, maximum pool depths and crested depth, thalweg profile, channel topography, and breaklines establishing the bank and extent of the survey reaching the first floodplain or other elevations beyond the bankfull.
3) The third crew member identifies and flags channel units and collects channel unit-level measurements, including LWD counts, fish cover estimates, and ocular estimates of substrates. Subsurface fines and pebble count measurements are collected in a subset of channel units.
4) The third crew member collects site-level metrics, including drawing the site map, conducting the water quality measurements, taking site and solar pathfinder photos, recording human influences, making riparian estimates, and taking drift net samples.
5) Everyone collects flags once the survey is completed.
129.qualifications: Prospective crew members will ideally have a background in biology, preferably in relation to fish, familiarity with GIS, basics of land surveying (e.g., using a total station), and experience living and working in the outdoors. Candidates must be able to work well with others, usually in a crew of 3-6, while enduring long and sometimes arduous days. Camping for multiple days and packing heavy loads of equipment in and out of sites is required periodically. Previous wilderness first aid knowledge is a plus, but not required.
129.trainingRequirements: All crew leaders and members will attend a 10 day pre-season training session. Crew will learn the theoretical background for the CHaMP protocol, proper use and maintenance of all field equipment, and procedures for data management.
129.safetyConsiderations: Each data collection organization will define safety constraints for accessing sites (e.g. sites must be less than 5 trail miles from a trail head and less than 1/2 mile from a trail or road). Sites will be rejected for sampling if the site falls outside these safety constraints.
129.fieldScheduleNotes:
Pre-Season (April-June 15th)	Document project, statistical design, and site evaluation metadata.

Field-Season (June 15-Sept 30th)	Daily data capture and quality assurance review of topographic and auxiliary data. Complete weekly quality assurance procedures and generated TIN file for each site. Perform weekly uploads of datasets to CHaMP website.

Post-Season (Oct 1- Oct 30th)	Ensure datasets are complete. Perform quality assurance on completed datasets and derived site-level metrics.
129.budgetConsiderations:
This protocol requires a wide range of equipment. One of the more expensive devices is the topographic surveying instrument required to survey each site. After some field trials, the CHaMP team settled on a Nikon Total Station:
http://www.nikon.com/about/technology/life/others/surveying/index.htm
129.name: CHaMP - John Day Watershed Habitat Monitoring Scientific Protocol for Salmonid Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) v1.0

sampleDesigns.title: Lemhi Watershed Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) for 2011

130.backgroundRationale: CHaMP is designed as a Columbia River basin-wide habitat status and trends monitoring program built around a single protocol with a programmatic approach to data collection and management (RM&E Workgroup 2010). CHaMP will result in the collection and analysis of systematic habitat status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide habitat conditions. When coupled with biological response indicators, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies. This program will be integrated with ongoing Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Program (PNAMP) recovery planning efforts and will be part of the collaborative process across Columbia Basin fish management agencies and tribes and other state and federal agencies that are monitoring anadromous salmonids and/or their habitat. The implementation of CHaMP will characterize stream responses to watershed restoration and/or management actions in at least one population within each steelhead and spring Chinook Major Population Group (MPG) which have, or will have, “fish-in” and “fish-out” monitoring (identified in RPA 50.6), thereby meeting the requirements of RPA 56.3, RPA 57, and RPA 3. CHaMP was designed to deliver trends in habitat indicators and requires that monitoring occurs for three cycles of a sampling panel (see section 1.6), at least 9 years.
objectives: The stream habitat data will be applied in conjunction with salmonid growth, survival, abundance and productivity data to estimate fish-habitat relationships across the Upper Columbia River Basin area

To generate standardized status and trend and effectiveness monitoring data for salmonid habitat in important Major Population Groups and spaitally diverse watersheds of the Columbia River Basin area.

To assess the quantity and quality of stream habitat for salmonids in wadeable, perennial streams below natural impassible barriers within Technical Recovery Team population boundaries across the UCRB
130.keyAssumptions: The protocol is structured around a general understanding of the link between habitat attributes and how they directly relate to the specific life history requirements of the salmonid fishes managed under the 2008 BiOp. These fish are likely not only responding to watershed and reach conditions but also to the conditions of individual channel units within reaches. Recognizing the importance of how interactions at the channel unit scale affect fish performance has led to an increased emphasis on the quantification of this important scale of fish habitat in the CHaMP protocol. We adopted the Hawkins et al. (1993) hierarchical classification scheme that allows for summarization of information across multiple scales. This preserves the ability to summarize information at the site scale as commonly practiced in major fish habitat monitoring programs throughout the Pacific Northwest as well as at the smaller channel-unit and topographical feature scales. The protocol employs spatially continuous sampling strategies using well-established surveying techniques to conduct precise topographic surveys from which digital elevation models (DEMs) can be produced. These topographic surveys are augmented by auxiliary data (e.g., channel classification, fish cover, substrate composition, distribution and embeddedness, large woody debris (LWD), solar input and water temperature, stream discharge, water chemistry, riparian structure, and site-level human influence) that help to characterize aspects of channel units that influence site-scale fish production potential. The CHaMP protocol draws together methods from many existing protocols as well as novel approaches to collecting and analyzing channel geomorphological data. The protocol is designed to collect data that fits within a geomorphological hierarchy spanning spatial scales ranging from within-unit topographical features to channel units to geomorphic to watershed and subbasin scales.
130.dataHandlingConsiderations: The CHaMP data management plan is integral to ensuring successful capture, quality assurance, and archiving of CHaMP field data along with the derivation and reporting of site-level metrics.  The data system will be comprised of field data capture tools and a centralized database with an online interface.  The online interface will support pre-season site evaluations, tracking project metadata, uploading field data, quality assurance procedures, and reporting derived metrics.  Under this plan, data will initially be captured on handheld field computers and then uploaded to the online database when internet connectivity is available.  A standard set of field data capture devices will be provided which will include data entry applications for the topographic and auxiliary habitat surveys.  This two-part system allows remote capture of data and centralized management of metadata, field measurements, and derived metrics.  Collectively, these tools support CHaMP’s data documentation, data capture, data quality, information archiving, standard metric calculation, and project reporting needs. Topographic survey data and auxiliary data will be captured using separate data logger applications.  Auxiliary data (wood loading, substrate composition, etc.) will be capture by a single crew member using a handheld field computer. The topography survey will create a raw topographic point file (x, y, z data) from which several geo-rectified products will be developed using survey (Leica Geo Office) and Arc GIS 10 software.  A triangular irregular network (TIN) and digital elevation model (DEM) will be created as the base topographic products from the survey.
130.qualityControlConsiderations:
Data quality assurance review will be conducted on a daily basis by crew members and on a weekly basis by the crew supervisor.  The quality assurance review will test for completeness, outliers in numeric data, and outliers in basic summary metrics.  At the end of each day, the crew member will be prompted to verify the number of channel units, total wood pieces, and number of drift samples.  Additionally, the crew will be prompted to review any values recorded as a missing value.  Next the crew will view and verify any numeric outliers. Finally, a short series of graphs will be presented to allow the crew to verify graphical data against their mental image of the site.  At the end of each week, the crew supervisor will perform a similar audit of the data. 
Data quality assurance for the topographic survey data will take place at four checkpoints within the flow of data from origination on the total station to data storage and web availability.  These checkpoints will reduce the likelihood of data errors compounding throughout data processing.  The four checkpoints are:
1.	Data origination (Total station)
2.	End of day data review (Total station/Data logger)
3.	End of week data processing and review (Laptop)
4.	Centralized database checks (CHaMP data system)
The crew lead is responsible for creation and submission of the original point file, a lines file (breaklines), a clean TIN, and a quality assurance report (table in geodatabase).  These should be produced within one week of initial data collection.
130.reportingConsiderations: Site-level metrics will be generated from data submitted to the CHaMP website.  These metrics will be presented in graphical and map format for all sites.  At the end of each field season, crew supervisors will review raw measurements and derived metrics for data completeness, numeric outliers, and ecologic sensibility.  Crew supervisors will be presented a series for graphs through the CHaMP website and asked to verify data quality.
130.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Total station and other equipment will be re-calibrated on an annual basis or more frequently as needed.
130.rolesAndResponsibilities:
1) The survey crew lays out the site, with two crew members monumenting the bottom of site and working upstream to the top placing transect flagging. The third crew member establishes monuments, benchmarks, control points, and potential survey set-up locations.

A site survey captures channel unit perimeters, maximum pool depths and crested depth, thalweg profile, channel topography, and breaklines establishing the bank and extent of the survey reaching the first floodplain or other elevations beyond the bankfull.
3) The third crew member identifies and flags channel units and collects channel unit-level measurements, including LWD counts, fish cover estimates, and ocular estimates of substrates. Subsurface fines and pebble count measurements are collected in a subset of channel units.
4) The third crew member collects site-level metrics, including drawing the site map, conducting the water quality measurements, taking site and solar pathfinder photos, recording human influences, making riparian estimates, and taking drift net samples.
5) Everyone collects flags once the survey is completed.
130.qualifications: Prospective crew members will ideally have a background in biology, preferably in relation to fish, familiarity with GIS, basics of land surveying (e.g., using a total station), and experience living and working in the outdoors. Candidates must be able to work well with others, usually in a crew of 3-6, while enduring long and sometimes arduous days. Camping for multiple days and packing heavy loads of equipment in and out of sites is required periodically. Previous wilderness first aid knowledge is a plus, but not required.
130.trainingRequirements: All crew leaders and members will attend a 10 day pre-season training session. Crew will learn the theoretical background for the CHaMP protocol, proper use and maintenance of all field equipment, and procedures for data management.
130.safetyConsiderations: Each data collection organization will define safety constraints for accessing sites (e.g. sites must be less than 5 trail miles from a trail head and less than 1/2 mile from a trail or road). Sites will be rejected for sampling if the site falls outside these safety constraints.

Field-Season (June 15-Sept 30th)	Daily data capture and quality assurance review of topographic and auxiliary data. Complete weekly quality assurance procedures and generated TIN file for each site. Perform weekly uploads of datasets to CHaMP website.

Post-Season (Oct 1- Oct 30th)	Ensure datasets are complete. Perform quality assurance on completed datasets and derived site-level metrics.

This protocol requires a wide range of equipment. One of the more expensive devices is the topographic surveying instrument required to survey each site. After some field trials, the CHaMP team settled on a Nikon Total Station:

To assess the quantity and quality of stream habitat for salmonids in wadeable, perennial streams below natural impassible barriers within Technical Recovery Team population boundaries across the UCRB
133.keyAssumptions: The protocol is structured around a general understanding of the link between habitat attributes and how they directly relate to the specific life history requirements of the salmonid fishes managed under the 2008 BiOp. These fish are likely not only responding to watershed and reach conditions but also to the conditions of individual channel units within reaches. Recognizing the importance of how interactions at the channel unit scale affect fish performance has led to an increased emphasis on the quantification of this important scale of fish habitat in the CHaMP protocol. We adopted the Hawkins et al. (1993) hierarchical classification scheme that allows for summarization of information across multiple scales. This preserves the ability to summarize information at the site scale as commonly practiced in major fish habitat monitoring programs throughout the Pacific Northwest as well as at the smaller channel-unit and topographical feature scales. The protocol employs spatially continuous sampling strategies using well-established surveying techniques to conduct precise topographic surveys from which digital elevation models (DEMs) can be produced. These topographic surveys are augmented by auxiliary data (e.g., channel classification, fish cover, substrate composition, distribution and embeddedness, large woody debris (LWD), solar input and water temperature, stream discharge, water chemistry, riparian structure, and site-level human influence) that help to characterize aspects of channel units that influence site-scale fish production potential. The CHaMP protocol draws together methods from many existing protocols as well as novel approaches to collecting and analyzing channel geomorphological data. The protocol is designed to collect data that fits within a geomorphological hierarchy spanning spatial scales ranging from within-unit topographical features to channel units to geomorphic to watershed and subbasin scales.
133.dataHandlingConsiderations: The CHaMP data management plan is integral to ensuring successful capture, quality assurance, and archiving of CHaMP field data along with the derivation and reporting of site-level metrics.  The data system will be comprised of field data capture tools and a centralized database with an online interface.  The online interface will support pre-season site evaluations, tracking project metadata, uploading field data, quality assurance procedures, and reporting derived metrics.  Under this plan, data will initially be captured on handheld field computers and then uploaded to the online database when internet connectivity is available.  A standard set of field data capture devices will be provided which will include data entry applications for the topographic and auxiliary habitat surveys.  This two-part system allows remote capture of data and centralized management of metadata, field measurements, and derived metrics.  Collectively, these tools support CHaMP’s data documentation, data capture, data quality, information archiving, standard metric calculation, and project reporting needs. Topographic survey data and auxiliary data will be captured using separate data logger applications.  Auxiliary data (wood loading, substrate composition, etc.) will be capture by a single crew member using a handheld field computer. The topography survey will create a raw topographic point file (x, y, z data) from which several geo-rectified products will be developed using survey (Leica Geo Office) and Arc GIS 10 software.  A triangular irregular network (TIN) and digital elevation model (DEM) will be created as the base topographic products from the survey.
133.qualityControlConsiderations:
Data quality assurance review will be conducted on a daily basis by crew members and on a weekly basis by the crew supervisor.  The quality assurance review will test for completeness, outliers in numeric data, and outliers in basic summary metrics.  At the end of each day, the crew member will be prompted to verify the number of channel units, total wood pieces, and number of drift samples.  Additionally, the crew will be prompted to review any values recorded as a missing value.  Next the crew will view and verify any numeric outliers. Finally, a short series of graphs will be presented to allow the crew to verify graphical data against their mental image of the site.  At the end of each week, the crew supervisor will perform a similar audit of the data. 
Data quality assurance for the topographic survey data will take place at four checkpoints within the flow of data from origination on the total station to data storage and web availability.  These checkpoints will reduce the likelihood of data errors compounding throughout data processing.  The four checkpoints are:
1.	Data origination (Total station)
2.	End of day data review (Total station/Data logger)
3.	End of week data processing and review (Laptop)
4.	Centralized database checks (CHaMP data system)
The crew lead is responsible for creation and submission of the original point file, a lines file (breaklines), a clean TIN, and a quality assurance report (table in geodatabase).  These should be produced within one week of initial data collection.
133.reportingConsiderations: Site-level metrics will be generated from data submitted to the CHaMP website.  These metrics will be presented in graphical and map format for all sites.  At the end of each field season, crew supervisors will review raw measurements and derived metrics for data completeness, numeric outliers, and ecologic sensibility.  Crew supervisors will be presented a series for graphs through the CHaMP website and asked to verify data quality.
133.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Total station and other equipment will be re-calibrated on an annual basis or more frequently as needed.
133.rolesAndResponsibilities:
1) The survey crew lays out the site, with two crew members monumenting the bottom of site and working upstream to the top placing transect flagging. The third crew member establishes monuments, benchmarks, control points, and potential survey set-up locations.
2) Once a site has been laid out, two crew members begin surveying the site. A site survey captures channel unit perimeters, maximum pool depths and crested depth, thalweg profile, channel topography, and breaklines establishing the bank and extent of the survey reaching the first floodplain or other elevations beyond the bankfull.
3) The third crew member identifies and flags channel units and collects channel unit-level measurements, including LWD counts, fish cover estimates, and ocular estimates of substrates. Subsurface fines and pebble count measurements are collected in a subset of channel units.
4) The third crew member collects site-level metrics, including drawing the site map, conducting the water quality measurements, taking site and solar pathfinder photos, recording human influences, making riparian estimates, and taking drift net samples.
5) Everyone collects flags once the survey is completed.
133.qualifications: Prospective crew members will ideally have a background in biology, preferably in relation to fish, familiarity with GIS, basics of land surveying (e.g., using a total station), and experience living and working in the outdoors. Candidates must be able to work well with others, usually in a crew of 3-6, while enduring long and sometimes arduous days. Camping for multiple days and packing heavy loads of equipment in and out of sites is required periodically. Previous wilderness first aid knowledge is a plus, but not required.
133.trainingRequirements: All crew leaders and members will attend a 10 day pre-season training session. Crew will learn the theoretical background for the CHaMP protocol, proper use and maintenance of all field equipment, and procedures for data management.
133.safetyConsiderations: Each data collection organization will define safety constraints for accessing sites (e.g. sites must be less than 5 trail miles from a trail head and less than 1/2 mile from a trail or road). Sites will be rejected for sampling if the site falls outside these safety constraints.
133.fieldScheduleNotes:
Pre-Season (April-June 15th)	Document project, statistical design, and site evaluation metadata.

Field-Season (June 15-Sept 30th)	Daily data capture and quality assurance review of topographic and auxiliary data. Complete weekly quality assurance procedures and generated TIN file for each site. Perform weekly uploads of datasets to CHaMP website.

Post-Season (Oct 1- Oct 30th)	Ensure datasets are complete. Perform quality assurance on completed datasets and derived site-level metrics.
133.budgetConsiderations:
This protocol requires a wide range of equipment. One of the more expensive devices is the topographic surveying instrument required to survey each site. After some field trials, the CHaMP team settled on a Nikon Total Station:
http://www.nikon.com/about/technology/life/others/surveying/index.htm
133.name: CHaMP - South Fork Salmon Watershed Habitat Monitoring Scientific Protocol for Salmonid Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) v1.0

sampleDesigns.title: Evaluate juvenile burbot growth and survival: WMA Ponds - Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG)

1136.backgroundRationale:
Burbot stock limitations become an increasing factor to restoration with each passing season. Because the Kootenai River burbot stock is so limited (Paragamian and Laude 2008), the introduction of a genetically similar donor stock was found to be a useful approach to enhance the population.

In the past few years, intensive culture techniques developed by the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho, BC Ministry of Environment, the UIARI, and Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) have become an important restoration measure for burbot on the Kootenai River. The management goal of this study is to restore the burbot population in the Idaho reach of the Kootenai River in order to provide an annual sustainable harvest of burbot.

To evaluate burbot early growth and survival in a natural environment, larvae were raised in two extensive rearing ponds. Burbot that are initially hatched at the University of Idaho Aquatic Research Institute (ARI) are reared in extensive ponds on Boundary Creek Wildlife Management Area to determine if survival and growth of juvenile burbot in a natural setting is higher than a hatchery setting. Two ponds currently exist for treatment studies. For hypothesis testing, additional ponds may be constructed to test concurrent treatment effects. Once these fish are released into the Kootenai River, survival of these pond reared burbot can be assessed. An example of test hypothesis are as follows: Null Hypothesis (Ho) tested: pond reared burbot survive at a higher rate than burbot reared in a hatchery through their juvenile life stage.

Aside from this protocol which deals directly with the pond rearing of these fish, the main Kootenai River will be sampled to determine if fish from these releases are surviving and recruiting to the adult population.  Sampling and survival estimates will be accomplished using Protocol # 548: KRRFM - Burbot Adult and Juvenile Stock Assessment (1988-065-00) v1.0.
objectives: Determine if pond raised burbot grow and survive better than those reared in a hatchery and stocked into the main Kootenai River.
Determine differences in growth and survival between ponds.
1136.keyAssumptions: Fish have an equal chance of being sampled once they are recruited to gear in the Kootenai River.
1136.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data from field studies pertaining to this protocol are entered directly into field computers them exported to access databases.  This reduces data transcription errors and increases efficiencies.  A single person has been assigned database management responsibilities and has 20 years experience.
1136.qualityControlConsiderations: In order to reduce the amount of duplicate errors, a single person checks the database on a regular basis.
1136.reportingConsiderations: Each day, electronic datasheets are downloaded and sent via email to the database coordinator.
1136.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Project Leader - Responsible for all facets of program management, training, budgeting, and directing subordinate personnel, data management and data analysis and report wrinting.

Lead technician - Responsible for field data collecting and data recording.

Database manager - Responsible for database management, data archiving, data analysis, and data manipulation in the the form of graphics for project leader for reports and manuscripts. 

Since this is a transboundary investigation, we will have an annual contract for this work to be performed in Canada with BC Ministry of Forests, Lands and Natural Resource Operations (BCMFLNRO).    Data collections methods in Canada will be identical to those performed in Idaho by IDFG.
1136.qualifications:
Mastrers degree required for Project Leader.

Bachelors degree required for subordinates.
1136.name: KRRFM - Burbot Early Life Studies: WMA Ponds (1988-065-00)

sampleDesigns.title: Survey Kokanee spawners - Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG)
Analyze and interpret Kokanee spawner data - Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG)

1147.backgroundRationale: An overall goal of the Dworshak Reservoir nutrient restoration project is to improve the efficiency of the foodweb, thereby increasing the size and abundance of kokanee in the reservoir to benefit the sport fishery and other resident fishes. In order to assess the effects of nutrient restoration on the abundance, size and fecundity of spawning kokanee, we examine a variety of metrics on an annual basis. Each fall, we conduct visual spawner counts for four index streams within three days of the historical peak of spawning activity.  We also collect pre-spawn kokanee from these index streams to evaluate size and fecundity.
objectives: Conduct spawner counts as an index of mature kokanee abundance.
Estimate mean length and weight of spawning Kokanee.
Estimate fecundity of spawning female Kokanee.
1147.keyAssumptions: Trends in index streams are indicative of the watershed as a whole.
1147.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data will be entered into standardized spreadsheets and databases.  Measures such as limiting the range of values that can be input or locking formulas will be used as appropriate. Data will be stored in multiple locations, including a network drive with a backup feature.
1147.qualityControlConsiderations: Data will be evaluated to make sure that values fall within expected ranges.
1147.reportingConsiderations: Progress reports will be prepared annually following the styles guideline for IDFG fisheries research reports. Manuscripts for peer reviewed journals will be prepared periodically following the style guidelines for the appropriate journal.
1147.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Waders and sampling equipment will be disinfected with Aquatic Virkon following spawner surveys.
1147.rolesAndResponsibilities: The technical lead will be responsible for planning and coordinating field surveys, oversee data collection and management, perform data analysis, and report results.  Crew members will be responsible for following data collection protocols and safety requirements.
1147.qualifications: The crew leader must have experience performing the particular survey.  Crew members must be able to follow data collection and safety protocols.  For spawner surveys, all crew members must be able to walk long distances over uneven, slippery terrain.
1147.trainingRequirements: On the job training will be provided for equipment and sampling techniques.  The technical lead should periodically attend workshops to stay current on sampling and analysis techniques.

1148.backgroundRationale:
Lake Pend Oreille (LPO) once provided the largest kokanee fishery in the state of Idaho. Between 1952 and 1966, harvests of kokanee averaged 1 million kokanee/yr with up to 523,000 angler-hours of fishing pressure (Jeppson 1953; Maiolie and Elam 1993). Kokanee harvest dramatically declined after 1966, and by 1985 the annual harvest was only 71,200 kokanee with 179,000 angler hours (Bowles et al. 1987; Maiolie and Elam 1993). The extent and timing of winter lake drawdowns has been implicated as most detrimental effect on the population (Maiolie and Elam 1993), but by the early 2000s, high predation levels created by a rapidly expanding lake trout was the primary limiting factor for kokanee.

One way to gauge the abundance of kokanee is through visual counts of spawning adults. These counts are conducted annually on both early and late spawning kokanee along index reaches (Jeppson 1960) in tributaries and along the shoreline dating back to 1972.
objectives: Conduct spawner counts as an index of mature kokanee abundance
1148.keyAssumptions: Visual spawner counts along shorelines or in tributaries are representative of the entire lake wide spawning component of the population.
1148.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are entered into excel generated forms manually. Data are then entered into an Access based database.
1148.qualityControlConsiderations: Once entered into a database, the project lead will provide quality control procedures by comparing field data sheets to data entered into electronic form.
1148.reportingConsiderations: Data will eventually be analyzed and reported in IDFG and BPA annual reports.
1148.rolesAndResponsibilities: Matt Corsi - Principal Fishery Research Biologist - Overall Program Lead Pete Rust - Senior Fishery Research Biologist - Project Lead, Oversees daily operations and project implementation Bill Harryman - Senior Fisheries Technician - Support Staff and main field data collection leader
1148.qualifications: Matt has a PhD in Fisheries Biology Pete has a Masters degree in Fisheries Biology Bill has a Bachelors Degree in Fisheries Biology
1148.trainingRequirements: First aid and CPR Swift water rescue On the job training in equipment use and operation
1148.safetyConsiderations: No specific training requirements but the field crew leader(s) have decades of experience operating watercraft and sampling equipment on large lakes at night under all weather conditions.
1148.name: LPO Kokanee Spawner Status Assessment

1152.backgroundRationale:
NOTE: The details in this protocol have been revised and are now contained in multiple protocols. Full details can now be found in protocol IDs: 549, 1985 & 2002; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/549; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/1985; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/2002

Burbot stock limitations become an increasing factor to restoration with each passing season. Because the Kootenai River burbot stock is so limited (Paragamian and Laude 2008), the introduction of a genetically similar donor stock was found to be a useful approach to enhance the population.

In the past few years, intensive culture techniques developed by the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho, BC Ministry of Environment, the UIARI, and Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) have become an important restoration measure for burbot on the Kootenai River. The management goal of this study is to restore the burbot population in the Idaho reach of the Kootenai River in order to provide an annual sustainable harvest of burbot.
objectives: Determine condition suitable for stocking burbot in tributaries of the Kootenai River.
Determine if burbot stocked into specific tributaries will return to their stocking location to spawn.
Determine differences in growth and survival between ponds.
Determine if pond raised burbot grow and survive better than those reared in a hatchery and stocked into the main Kootenai River.
Describe fish assemblage and population-level relationships with habitat.
Evaluate efficacy of sampling techniques for fish assemblages and the influence of habitat characteristics on detectability.
1152.keyAssumptions: Fish have an equal chance of being sampled once they are recruited to gear in the Kootenai River.

1153.backgroundRationale:
NOTE: The details in this protocol have been revised and are now contained in multiple protocols. Full details can now be found in protocol IDs: 546, 547, & 1997;

Significant wild sturgeon recruitment has not occurred in the Kootenai River since at least 1972. Hatchery production from Kootenai Tribe of Idaho (KTOI) began in 1990. To evaluate the successes of the KTOI hatchery program and to evaluate the effects of mitigative flows provided by Libby Dam beginning in 1991, juvenile sturgeon sampling became a standard operating procedure beginning in 1978 (Partridge 1983). We evaluate survival, growth, disease presence, condition, and movements of hatchery reared juvenile sturgeon. Although significant wild recruitment is lacking, we catch about 10 wild recruits each year. Gill nets are the best method for evaluating significant recruitment.
objectives: Restore natural recruitment of Kootenai River white sturgeon
1153.keyAssumptions:
All hatchery released juvenile sturgeon are marked;
River scale sampling issues will obscure results;
 Our gear are effective at sampling drifting larvae.

sampleDesigns.title: Assess kokanee population status - Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG)

1155.backgroundRationale:
NOTE: The details in this protocol have been revised and are now contained in multiple protocols. Full details can now be found in protocol IDs: 613 & 2016; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/613; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/2016

 

An overall goal of the Dworshak Reservoir nutrient restoration project is to improve the efficiency of the foodweb, thereby increasing the size and abundance of kokanee in the reservoir to benefit the sport fishery and other resident fishes. In order to assess the effects of nutrient restoration on the kokanee population, we examine a variety of metrics on an annual basis. We assess kokanee size, age structure and reproductive development using biological data obtained from mid-water trawl surveys conducted in July. Furthermore, we estimate age-specific abundance, survival rates, biomass, production and total mortality by weight. We will evaluate kokanee growth either through length back-calculations from scale analysis, additional trawl surveys conducted in the spring and fall, or a combination of the two. Each fall, we collect pre-spawn kokanee from index streams to evaluate size and fecundity. We conduct visual spawner counts for four index streams within three days of the historical peak of spawning activity.
objectives: Estimate kokanee biomass, production and mortality by weight.
Estimate kokanee age-specific survival.
Estimate kokanee age-specific abundance.
Estimate age specific mean length, weight and relative weight.
Estimate fecundity of spawning female Kokanee.
Estimate mean length and weight of spawning Kokanee.
Conduct spawner counts as an index of mature kokanee abundance.
1155.keyAssumptions: Trends in index streams are indicative of the watershed as a whole.
1155.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data will be entered into standardized spreadsheets and databases.  Measures such as limiting the range of values that can be input or locking formulas will be used as appropriate. Data will be stored in multiple locations, including a network drive with a backup feature.
1155.qualityControlConsiderations: Data will be evaluated to make sure that values fall within expected ranges.  Scale reading will be performed by at least two independent readers, and discrepancies will be resolved by re-analyzing scales and performing length back calculations to determine if identified annuli are reasonable based on back calculated lengths.  Echograms of a calibration sphere will be recorded prior to acoustic surveys to verify proper calibration of the equipment.
1155.reportingConsiderations: Progress reports will be prepared annually following the styles guideline for IDFG fisheries research reports. Manuscripts for peer reviewed journals will be prepared periodically following the style guidelines for the appropriate journal.
1155.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration:
Immediately prior to the July trawl survey, the trawl net will be calibrated as described in our trawl survey methods. The trawler will be disinfected using a steam cleaner at Clearwater Fish Hatchery. The net will be disinfected using bleach or Aquatic Virkon prior to storage. The net will also be inspected and repaired as necessary in between surveys.

The echosounder will be calibrated annually per the manufacturer's instructions. Prior to each survey, calibration will be checked using a standard calibration sphere as described in our acoustic methods.

Waders and sampling equipment will be disinfected with Aquatic Virkon following spawner surveys.
1155.rolesAndResponsibilities: The technical lead will be responsible for planning and coordinating field surveys, oversee data collection and management, perform data analysis, and report results.  Crew members will be responsible for following data collection protocols and safety requirements.
1155.qualifications: The crew leader must have experience performing the particular survey at hand.  For on the water surveys (i. e. trawling and acoustics) the crew leader must be experienced in boat operation, safety and navigation during hours of darkness.  Crew members must be able to follow data collection and safety protocols.  For spawner surveys, all crew members must be able to walk long distances over uneven, slippery terrain.
1155.trainingRequirements: On the job training will be provided for equipment and sampling techniques.  The technical lead should periodically attend workshops to stay current on sampling and analysis techniques.
1155.safetyConsiderations: Personal flotation devices will be provided when working on the water.  Safety will be discussed with the crew prior to surveying, including appropriate responses to particular emergency situations.
1155.name: Assess Kokanee Population Status Interim Protocol

1158.backgroundRationale:
NOTE: The details in this protocol have been revised and are now contained in multiple protocols. Full details can now be found in protocol IDs: 788, 1853 & 1854; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/788; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/1853; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/1854

In an alluvial aquifer system that often in direct communication with surface water, groundwater monitoring is essential to understanding how the hydrologic system functions. Correlating groundwater levels to reaches of high seepage loss in rivers help to understand where and what kind of projects can help restore historic groundwater levels and increase stream flows.
objectives: Prepare groundwater data for use in other studies, including model development, watershed planning, groundwater/surface water interactions and others
Collect groundwater data at wells with both continuous data loggers and quarterly manual water level measurements.
Monitor surface water temperatures during the summer, fall and early winter.
Quantify stream flow, especially with the use of data loggers for analysis of stream trends and status.
Provide stream flow information to partners for use in decision making.
1158.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are entered on to a field data sheet and then transferred into the AQUARIUS database at our office.  Data are graphed to ensure accuracy of transfers.  Data storage is backed-up constantly using a RAID system.  Data is available through our website - www.wwbwc.org.
1158.qualityControlConsiderations: Water level measurements are taking twice to verify that values are accurate.  Data from the loggers are corrected to manual water level measurements.
1158.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Most equipment used in our groundwater monitoring network does not need to be calibrated.  Temperature and conductivity meter is calibrated on a year basis by ODEQ.
1158.rolesAndResponsibilities: Steven Patten (Senior Environmental Scientist) - Groundwater monitoring - Lead - Oversee groundwater activities and review data; Lyndsi Hersey (Environmental Scientist) - Groundwater monitoring - Collect, process and analysis groundwater data and manage the data in the AQUARIUS database and post data online; Will Lewis (Environmental Scientist) - Groundwater Monitoring  - Collect, process and analysis groundwater data and manage the data in the AQUARIUS database and post data online.
1158.qualifications: Basic understanding of hydrology, hydrogeology, and water quality.
1158.trainingRequirements: Review procedures for groundwater monitoring (including documents from USGS, WDOE, and others).
1158.fieldScheduleNotes: Quarterly monitoring needed to collect manual water level measurements and ensure data loggers are still operating correctly.
1158.name: Recharge Project & Water Monitoring Interim Protocol

1161.backgroundRationale:
NOTE: Some details in this protocol are no longer being implemented. For the most up to date version of the protocol, please see protocol ID: 586;  https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/586 

Lake Pend Oreille once provided the largest kokanee fishery in the state of Idaho. Between 1952 and 1966, harvests of kokanee averaged 1 million kokanee/yr with up to 523,000 angler-hours of fishing pressure (Jeppson 1953; Maiolie and Elam 1993). Additionally, kokanee are the forage base that allows Gerrard rainbow trout in Lake Pend Oreille reach trophy sizes, including the former world record. However, kokanee abundance declined, and in the early 2000s they were at risk of complete collapse (Hansen et al. 2010). High predation rates created by a rapidly expanding lake trout was the primary limiting factor for kokanee, but as a part of kokanee recovery, rainbow trout harvest was also liberalized during 2006-2012.

Kokanee have since rebounded in Lake Pend Oreille, and restrictive harvest regulations have been instituted for rainbow trout that are designed to improve population size structure and re-build the trophy fishery. With restrictive regulations again in place and a resurgent kokanee population, we sample rainbow trout to characterize age and growth rates for this population. Anglers are the most effective tool for capturing rainbows, so we coordinate sampling with fishing derbies. Samples are collected across all sizes of fish in the population. Results are compared to previous work in recent years to evaluate the response of rainbow trout to these changes.
objectives: Calculate rainbow trout growth rate
Calculate rainbow trout condition factor
1161.keyAssumptions: Rainbow trout sampled are representative of the entire population.
1161.name: LPO Rainbow Trout Population Assessment (1994-047-00) Interim Protocol

sampleDesigns.title: Collect Scales from CJH Spring and Summer/Fall Broodstock - Colville Confederated Tribes
Process CWT Snouts at CJH Lab - Colville Confederated Tribes
Sampling Adult Return to Hatchery - Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife

1163.backgroundRationale: The Select Area Fisheries Enhancement (SAFE) Program produces Chinook and coho salmon for commercial and recreational harvest in off-channel and terminal areas in the Lower Columbia River. Fish for this program are reared at and/or released from Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW) hatcheries (Gnat Creek and Klaskanine), a Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) hatchery (Grays River), a hatchery owned and operated by Clatsop County (South Fork Klaskanine) and net pens in Youngs Bay, Blind Slough, Tongue Point and Deep River (Washington). Some adult Chinook that are not caught in the commercial or recreational fisheries return to the hatcheries previously mentioned (except Gnat Creek as there is no adult collection trap at this hatchery).  Fish collected from the traps are biologically sampled to obtain information on species, stock, age, and size. These data are used in conjunction with surveys of sport and commercial fisheries and spawning grounds to reconstruct the adult salmonid returns of fish released from the SAFE Program. The sampling outlined in this protocol specifically addresses the work performed at two of the SAFE funded hatcheries, Klaskanine and South Fork Klaskanine Hatcheries, and represents the data collection methods only. The data collected using this protocol is used in the analysis described in Protocol ID 2041 Run Reconstruction and Fishery Contribution Analysis for the Select Area Fishery Enhancement (SAFE) Program.
objectives: Sample adult returns of Select Area Bright fall Chinook at Klaskanine and South Fork Klaskanine Hatcheries annually to depict stocks present, and age structure of the returning population
1163.keyAssumptions:
We assume that Coded Wire Tags (CWTs) can be consistently detected using Northwest Marine Technology (NMT) wands and tunnel detectors.

We assume that fin marks are recognizable.

We assume that the age structure (scale) can be accurately read.
1163.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are entered into a handheld data logger in the field and are later uploaded to a computer and printed. Samples taken (scales and snouts) are labeled to correspond with the sampling event.
1163.qualityControlConsiderations: There are several error checks programmed into the handheld data logger to prevent omissions, keystroke errors, and data entered out of sequence. Data and samples are verified by a data technician. CWT wands are tested often using a detection standard to verify that the wand is functioning properly. Fish scales are inspected as they are sampled to ensure that they are of good readable quality.
1163.reportingConsiderations: The data collected on the handheld data logger are uploaded to a regional database owned and operated by Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife. The database, Coded Wire Tag Fish (CWTF), stores the data and allows a user to make edits to, view, and download the data.
1163.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: All sampling equipment are cleaned thoroughly after each sampling event. Broken or worn items are replace and/or repaired.
1163.rolesAndResponsibilities: The crew lead is responsible for coordinating with hatchery staff and sampling adult fish at the hatcheries during spawning and/or killing operations. The crew lead may be assisted by one to two crew members depending on the volume of fish to be sampled.
1163.qualifications: All crew members will be experienced in species identification of adult salmonids and the applicable sampling techniques.
1163.trainingRequirements: Crew leaders will will have at least an Associate Science degree in fisheries or 18 months of experience in aquaculture or a related field and all crew members will have received training by agency staff in sampling methodology.
1163.safetyConsiderations: Crew members will be briefed on safety precautions annually and will required to complete an online hazardous materials training.
1163.fieldScheduleNotes: Sampling is coordinated with hatchery staff so that it coincides with normal spawning or removal of fish.
1163.budgetConsiderations: CWT detection wands are relatively expensive ($3750 per unit).
1163.name: Sampling Adult Salmonids Returning to SAFE Hatcheries

1165.backgroundRationale:
Terminal fisheries were developed as a means to increase recreational and commercial harvest of hatchery fish while providing greater protection for weak stocks of salmon and steelhead including those protected under the Endangered Species Act.  The SAFE project has four current Select Area fishing sites: Youngs Bay, Blind Slough/Knappa Slough and Tongue Point/South Channel in Oregon and Deep River in Washington.  Each site provides both recreational and commercial fishing opportunities, although season structure and target species differ with current management goals and production strategies.

Being located at the mouth of the Columbia River, albeit in terminal, off-channel areas, the SAFE Program prosecutes mixed-stock fisheries.  Fishers from both Oregon and Washington participate in SAFE fisheries (Washington SAFE fishers are allowed to fish in Oregon SAFE sites as well as Deep River in Washington).  The SAFE fishery is highly managed so that most SAFE-produced salmon are caught and impacts to ESA-listed stocks are minimized.  Few salmon produced by this program escape to hatcheries or streams to spawn; this varies by stock with tule and SAB fall Chinook escapement between 9% and 11% and coho and spring Chinook 4% to 5%, respectively for brood years 2000-2014 (Table 1).  While SAFE fishers mostly catch SAFE-produced fish, particularly spring Chinook and coho, there are other Columbia River stocks that are represented in SAFE landings.  The winter/spring/summer (WSS) Chinook fishery is an example in which a number of non-SAFE stocks are found in SAFE catch (Table 2).  SAFE stocks include spring Chinook and Select Area Bright (SAB) fall Chinook that return early (in June and July).  The most critical stock that is caught in the WSS spring Chinook SAFE fishery is the upriver Columbia River spring Chinook because it is the ESA-listed stock that limits SAFE fishers when impacts mount to the degree that encroaches upon the allowable catch balance.  To prosecute these mixed-stock fisheries in a riverine system with eight ESA-listed Columbia River salmon species (or distinct population segments, https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/species-directory), a great deal of monitoring and management is involved.  The SAFE fisheries must be sampled when catch is delivered to buyers, not only to determine the quantity caught, recorded on fish tickets, but bio-sampling to observe fin clips that indicate specific stocks, such as SABs, and whether snouts contain coded-wire tags (CWT), and scales collected for aging (see protocol 1772: Fish Sampling for the Select Area Fisheries Enhancement (SAFE) Program). 

During fisheries sampling, snouts are scanned for CWTs.  If present, they are sent to labs for codes to be deciphered and reported to agencies who link associated data (e.g., stock, date released and by whom, etc.).  Data from recovered CWTs are used for four purposes: 1) to validate VSIs by comparing the “stock call” to the stock linked to the tag code; 2) for cohort reconstruction of SAFE produced salmon, each release having a unique CWT code, that is used to estimate abundance of SAFE-produced CWT release groups, in sequential years from age 2 to the end of the cohort’s life span, that are represented in sport and commercial ocean and river landings and escapement of salmon recorded on the spawning grounds and that return to hatcheries; 3) once the cohort’s life span has ended and a full cohort reconstruction is completed for each of SAFE Program’s CWT release groups, smolt-to-adult survival rates are calculated to examine project effectiveness, and; 4) run reconstruction allocates what stocks contribute to mixed-stock fisheries, in this case Select Area fisheries, and includes SAFE-produced and non-SAFE produced CWT release groups.  The SAFE Program uses run reconstruction to show proportions of all stocks caught in in SAFE WSS and fall fisheries, while cohort reconstruction is used to show what fisheries SAFE-produced releases were landed and SAS rates.  Stock and age composition of SAFE landings are summarized using data on landings, obtained by fish tickets, CWT recoveries to validate VSI stock calls, and ages assigned by scale analysis, both obtained from sampling fisheries.

During the WSS fishery, spring Chinook is the focus and impacts to upriver spring Chinook generally limits the fishery.  Sturgeon are also allocated for SAFE fishers and landings often include both spring Chinook and sturgeon.  SAFE fisheries during fall includes sturgeon, if allocated catch remains, fall Chinook (tules and brights), and coho.  In fall, CWTs are relied upon to a greater extent for in-season management of fall Chinook fisheries but VSI protocols are used to distinguish tules from brights.  For some stocks, high CWT rates allow for sufficient recoveries of CWTs for management purposes.  Since the life-history of coho dictates that they almost always return as age-3 and there are either native, late-returning Lower Columbia River (type N) or hatchery-influenced, early-returning coho (type S).  Generally, type S return in September and October and type N return in November and December.  Because of the difference in return timing, type N coho can be managed by ending the fishery before the run begins in earnest.  Many coho caught in during fall by SAFE fishers have CWTs, which are processed the same as Chinook.
objectives: Determine stock and age composition of commercial harvest in Select Area sites
Reconstruct Select Area spring and fall Chinook run sizes
Determine Smolt-to-Adult Survival Rates (SARs) for SAFE releases of Chinook and coho
Determine ex-vessel value of commercial landings in Select Areas
1165.dataHandlingConsiderations: To determine stock and age composition of salmon caught in SAFE fisheries bio-sampling data collected during fisheries sampling used for this are number of salmon inspected, fin marks observed and recorded, scales read and aged, and CWTs recovered and deciphered.  Sampling summaries contain the commercial zone sampled, landing date, sample identification number, buyer, bio-sample rate, number of salmon inspected for fin mark, number of salmon for which biological samples were collected (scales, tissue samples for genetic analysis), total weight of fish sampled, average weight of fish sampled, PIT tag codes read, and number of snouts removed for CWT inspection.  Snouts are given an identification number, bagged and sent to labs in Clackamas, Oregon or Olympia, Washington, where the CWT is extracted and decoded.  The resulting tag code is entered and verified by Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission’s (PSMFC) Regional Mark Information System (RMIS), which is a region-wide clearinghouse for coded-wire tag data (https://www.rmpc.org).  Associated fishery-recovery and biological data for each CTW code deciphered from snouts collected during fishery sampling, are uploaded to RMIS and are merged with previously entered CWT recovery data.  CWT data is used to verify visual stock idenfication, calculate run reconstruction and smolt-to-adult suvival rates.  Data for determining ex-vessel value are collected on fish tickets turned in to ODFW by fish buyers that includes number of fish, pounds per fish, and price paid.  ODFW staff enters this data into a database and summarizes prices paid per stock/season/Select Area site and reports these values.
1165.qualityControlConsiderations: The first three objectives of this study plan hinge on recovered CWTs and associated data.  There are levels of quality control that are part of the reporting process as the information goes from the technicians reading the tag codes, returning data to hatcheries, and staff at agencies that scrutinize and maintain the database that is the repository and finally, when agency staff submits data to RMIS, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission staff complete their review.   Ex-vessel value data are entered, reviewed, and as it is used for reporting, further review is done.
1165.reportingConsiderations: There is a short turn-around time required for fisheries sampling data and fish tickets turned in by buyers because important the important management decision of whether to rescind fishing periods, so as not to exceed ESA allotted impacts, hinge on the results.  However, there are different time frames depending on use of the data.  Data used in annual or multi-year reports are on a longer time frame than management decisions, and to calculate smolt-to-adult survival rates for CWT groups requires four to five years for the cohort to have all returned (Figure 2).
1165.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: The only equipment used in this study plan is for the first objective, which is to sample SAFE fisheries (protocol 3577).  The other objectives are analyses.  Fisheries sampling crews are fitted with sampling kits that contain equipment for measuring and weighing, collecting scales, tissue, and snouts, wands for detecting CWT, PIT tags, and recording data.  Maintenance includes cleaning equipment that comes in contact with fish, keeping the kit supplied, and the battery charged for wands and tablets.
1165.name: Run Reconstruction and Fishery Contribution Analysis for the Select Area Fishery Enhancement (SAFE) Program

1166.backgroundRationale:
This document was developed to provide consistency with how habitat variable data is collected throughout the Columbia Basin Region in support of the Columbia River Wildlife Mitigation Program funded by Bonneville Power Administration (BPA). This publication is a “stand alone” reference for Habitat Evaluation Procedures (HEP) and Combined Habitat Assessment Protocols (CHAP) transect techniques used by the Regional HEP Team (RHT).

This document is intended to be a “user friendly” habitat variable measurement technique manual for both novice and experienced field technicians alike. As a result, theory and mathematical/statistical discussions are held to a minimum. It is assumed that field technicians will possess the specific measuring devices discussed in this manual. Thus, device descriptions are limited in most cases.

English measurements e. g., inches, feet, etc., are used to accommodate measurements found in many HEP models and because English measurements are better understood by the general public. English measurements can easily be converted to metric equivalents if needed.

General and specific protocols are described in the following sections. General protocols include a brief description of pre HEP survey pilot studies; transect establishment guidelines, and photo documentation parameters. In contrast, specific metrics detail actual habitat variable measurement techniques including diagrams where additional explanation is needed. In cases where more than one measurement technique option is possible, options are assigned an alpha-numeric code. This allows project managers and field technicians to identify specific measurement techniques in report tables and data spreadsheets without lengthy, redundant explanations.

This field techniques manual is intended to be a “living” document and will be modified as needed.
