The following standardized protocols and measurement techniques are used by the Regional HEP team to measure habitat variables described in HEP models and used in conjunction with CHAP verification transects.
objectives: Provide consistency with how habitat variable data is collected throughout the Columbia Basin Region in support of the Columbia River Wildlife Mitigation Program funded by BPA.
1166.keyAssumptions: Our key assumption is that HEP species models can be used to quantify habitat quality for individual wildlife species and species guilds.
1166.dataHandlingConsiderations: All field data is recorded on data loggers or field data forms. Data is entered into computer spreadsheets, and submitted with HEP reports for each entity. If HEP data is recorded on hard copy (i.e., paper) data sheets due to weather conditions, hard copy data sheets will also be provided to project sponsors.
1166.qualityControlConsiderations:
Habitat variable data collection protocols are reviewed each field day. Field personnel are "calibrated" for spatial measurements based on team consensus methods. After field measurements are taken, field team leaders review the data to ensure the data  makes "biological sense." In addition, transect photos are compared to field data results in the office to support measured data results.  Refer to the accompanying diagram for the following explanation: HEP model variable data is entered onto Allegro CE® data logger spreadsheets (1), or recorded on paper data sheets in the field (2). The raw field data (3) is downloaded from the data loggers or manually entered from paper data sheets onto computers (transect photos were also downloaded and stored on field computers). The raw data and photos are compiled for each transect into three basic products/files (4) that are provided to project managers as report appendices and/or separate CD files. 
Product files include raw field data downloaded from the data loggers (5), data summary spreadsheets (6) which are the results of compiling/processing the raw data, and transect photo files (7). Summarized/processed data from each transect is applied to appropriate HEP model variables to determine suitability index (SI) ratings that are combined on habitat suitability index (HSI) spreadsheets (8) to determine the HSI for a particular HEP species model/cover type. The habitat suitability index is then multiplied by the number of cover type acres to determine the number of habitat units (9). Habitat variable data computations are reviewed by three reviewers.
1166.reportingConsiderations: HEP survey habitat unit (HU) results must be uploaded to BPA's Pisces database along with final HEP survey reports. In addition, project sponsors and BPA COTRs receive a copy of final HEP reports along with supporting document links/folders. Reporting time frames coincide with BPA contract milestones.
1166.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Vehicles are washed, including under carriage, after completing a HEP analysis on a given project site, or when moving to a different geographical location. This includes washing vehicles on weekends after returning to "home of record" before returning to a project site to continue HEP surveys. Team member field clothes and boots are also cleaned of seed, foliage, and other debris between projects and/or weekly whichever comes first. Equipment does not need recalibration. It is either functional or it is not.
1166.rolesAndResponsibilities: Crew leaders are responsible for hiring, training, and materially supporting crew members, planning and executing HEP surveys, controlling data quality and storage, calculating data results, applying data results to HEP models, and drafting final HEP reports. Crew members are responsible for collecting habitat data, maintaining vehicles, and assisting with data computations and other tasks as assigned.
1166.qualifications: Crew lead must be HEP certified, well versed in habitat variable collection methods and associated statistical analyses and plant identification; possess strong leadership, computer program and writing skills; be physically capable of participating in habitat surveys; College degree and or sufficient course work in natural resources or related field(s). Crew members should possess post high school education or a degree in natural resources or related field(s);  be physically capable of participating in habitat surveys; possess computer program and plant identification skills.
1166.trainingRequirements: Both crew leaders and crew members should receive training in the following areas: Habitat variable measured and ocular data collection techniques; the use and care of data collection equipment/tools; cover type identification; map orientation; HEP species model requirements; and plant identification.
1166.safetyConsiderations: All crew members should possess comfortable hiking boots, hat, weather appropriate clothing including rain gear, orange safety vest, water bottle(s) or backpack water "camel", intra team radio, insect spray, sunscreen etc. Crew leaders should conduct daily safety briefings that include at the minimum: expected weather conditions, project area terrain features, how to deal with potential hazards such as rattlesnakes, cliffs, lightening, encounters with large predators and hostile people, etc., time away from vehicle, first-aid kit locations, actions to take and who to contact in the event of an accident, location of vehicle key.
1166.fieldScheduleNotes: Hire temporary field technicians attending college in January or February in order to have the largest candidate pool possible. Pre-visit project sites to determine access, learn terrain features, confirm cover types and HEP model species selection, identify special equipment needs such as mud boots etc.. Pre-package cover type/boundary maps, HEP models, and other data related forms for each project site. Conduct HEP surveys May through mid September predicated on HEP model requirements e.g., a mallard nesting HEP model survey should take place during the nesting season.
1166.budgetConsiderations: I highly recommend using data loggers to log habitat variable data. This allows the data to be uploaded to computer spreadsheets, thus reducing time spent on calculating data results and reducing errors due to handling the data more than once. Data loggers can be expensive. Crew travel and per diem costs can also be a significant part of the budget if project areas are far from the crew's "home of record" or located far apart.
1166.name: Habitat Evaluation Procedures (HEP)

1168.backgroundRationale: This document details the monitoring design, procedures, and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of restoration projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s (BPA) programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: A programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program." This is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol,–“Monitoring Effectiveness of Fish Passage Projects” (ID: 34) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/DownloadDescription/34), and the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID: 18) (https://www.monitoringresources.org/ Resources/Program/Detail/18); however, variations in the monitoring design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.
objectives: Determine whether juvenile salmonid density and abundance by channel unit in a restored reach is increasing relative to a control reach.
1168.keyAssumptions:
Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided prior to project implementation and for a period of five years following project completion.

Reach is suitable for snorkel surveys.
1168.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data will be collected in the field using various hand-held data entry devices.  Raw data will be kept on file by the project monitoring entity.  A copy of all raw data will be provided to the BPA at the end of the project.  Summarized data from the project will be entered into the online database after each sampling season.
1168.qualityControlConsiderations: All data collected in the field is uploaded into a replication of the database on a laptop computer and run through a series of QA/QC checks prior to leaving the site.  In addition to the automated QA/QC process, this allows field staff to visually review the data for errors.  Should errors or omissions be found, field staff can correct items that may be recorded improperly or collect additional data that may be missing from the data forms while still onsite.
1168.reportingConsiderations:
A progress report will be prepared in writing by the monitoring entity after the sampling season for Years 1 and 2, including preliminary results.  A final report will be prepared in writing by the monitoring entity after the sampling season for Year 5.  It shall include: 
•	Estimates of precision and variance 
•	Confidence limits for data 
•	Summarized data required for PRISM database 
•	Determination whether project met decision criteria for effectiveness 
•	Analysis of completeness of data, sources of bias
.
1168.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration:
Field equipment (i.e., waders, wading socks, boots, dry suits, snorkel equipment or any other field gear) should be maintained to prevent the spread of disease or invasive species.  This can be accomplished by thoroughly cleaning equipment prior to leaving a site or at the office prior to using that equipment at another location.  

Electronic equipment should be maintained in good working condition to ensure that measurements are collected and recorded accurately.  This includes ensuring that equipment is fully charged or has sufficient battery power to operate correctly, as well as any calibration that may be required or recommended by manufacturers.
1168.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Field Manager (FM):  The Field Manager is responsible for and has the authority to direct all operations related to the field work necessary to complete this project.  The Field Manager oversees all field crews and is directly responsible for insuring that all safety procedures are followed.  The Field Manager shall be directly responsible for the safety of all field crews when in the field and for strictly following a daily field plan.  He/She shall implement an established emergency plan at the field level should an emergency situation arise.  The Field Manager will know the location of crews and their itineraries at all times and shall keep the field team leaders advised of significant project developments on a daily basis by providing and following a daily field plan or itinerary.  

Field Team Leader (FTL): Each Field Team Leader shall be directly responsible for the safety of his or her field crew when in the field and for strictly following the daily field plan.  Each FTL shall implement the emergency plan at the field level during emergency situations.  Each FTL in the field shall know the location of his or her field crew and their itineraries at all times and shall keep the other FTLs advised of significant project developments on a daily basis by providing and following a daily field plan or itinerary.  

Field Investigators: Each field investigator shall be responsible for following the Health and Safety Plan.  He or she shall maintain scheduled communications with the FTL and shall assure that during emergency situations appropriate procedures are followed. In the event the FTL is incapacitated or unavailable, the most senior field investigator shall assume the duties of the FTL.
1168.qualifications:
Field Manager: The FM must have experience with the type of work that is being conducted and must be familiar with all field operations related to the field work.  The FM must also be familiar with safety and emergency procedures and be capable of overseeing and/or carrying out any necessary tasks associated with those procedures.  

Field Team Leader: The most experienced member of every field team will be designated as the FTL.  The FTL must also be familiar with safety and emergency procedures and be capable of carrying out any necessary tasks associated with those procedures.  

Field Investigator:  The field investigators must be trained in the type of work that is being conducted or have sufficient experience/education to be capable of conducting the necessary tasks and adhering to safety policies.
1168.trainingRequirements:
An interdisciplinary training session and site-specific orientation shall be given to all field personnel by personnel who have used the protocols for at least three years prior to beginning site work.  This training may be internal, or contracted using personnel who have already implemented these protocols to ensure consistency across organizations.  The training shall cover materials related to health and safety procedures as well as technical aspects of the work to be performed.  This training shall also be provided to any new employees arriving after the start of the field season before they begin field work.  

The Field Manager will conduct field safety meetings and prior to the start of any new activities.  These meetings will provide the chance for field personnel to present questions or address any safety issues that may have arisen
1168.safetyConsiderations: At least two team members of each field team will be current with their first aid/CPR training.  First aid/CPR training is recommended for any subcontractors.  A copy of the Health and Safety Plan shall accompany each field team into the field. Field staff must always work in teams of 2 or more and may never work alone.  At the end of each work day, the FTL will check in with the Field Manager to confirm that all team members are accounted for and have left the site safely.  Check in can be done by leaving a phone message for the Field Manager.
1168.fieldScheduleNotes: Surveys are scheduled to coincide with summer low flow conditions whenever possible.  Monitoring of the impact and control reaches should be conducted consecutively to capture similar flow and environmental conditions at each reach.  Monitoring of a site should be conducted during each monitoring year on a schedule similar to that of the previous years so that seasonal fluctuations in stream conditions, riparian habitat, and fish use are not an issue.  For spawner surveys, sampling should occur in both the impact and control stream reaches beginning with the earliest anticipated spawning for the target species and should continue until the end of the normal spawning period.
1168.budgetConsiderations: For each project, a team of 2-4 field staff surveying for two 10-hour days (1 day control, 1 day impact) is budgeted.  The number of field staff required is dependent on the size of the site and the level of effort that will be required to collect all data at both reaches within the two-day period.   Additionally, a team of 2 field staff for one 10-hour day is budged for each visit to each site during spawner surveys.  In order to reduce costs associated with travel and mobilization, monitoring of sites within the same geographic region may be grouped such that multiple sites can be surveyed during a given trip.
1168.name: Coordinated MBACI Protocol for Estimating Instream Juvenile Salmonid Abundance_AEM

sampleDesigns.title: Ecological Interactions M&E in the Yakima River Basin - Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW)

1170.backgroundRationale:
The YKFP is a joint project of the Yakama Nation (lead entity) and the Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW), and is sponsored in large part by the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) with oversight and guidance from the Northwest Power and Conservation Council (NPCC). The Cle Elum Supplementation and Research Facility (CESRF) program is an adaptively managed supplementation program designed "to test the assumption that new artificial production can be used to increase harvest and natural production while maintaining the long-term genetic fitness of the fish population being supplemented and keeping adverse genetic and ecological interactions with non-target species or stocks within acceptable limits".

The non-target taxa of concern monitoring program under the YKFP was established to assess and contain risks to species that were not the target of enhancement during the operation of the production scale hatchery supplementation program in the Yakima Basin.  The NTTOC monitoring program (ecological risk containment) was initiated to ensure ecological interactions resulting from our supplementation program remained within acceptable limits.  Benchmark values were established for abundance, size, and distribution for NTTOC and changes in these monitoring variables are judged relative to these fixed standards.  Deviations in our monitoring variables that exceed acceptable levels are intended to be mitigated using the principles of adaptive management.
objectives: Assess and contain risks to abundance, size structure, biomass, and distribution for 15 NTTOC associated with hatchery salmon supplementation in the Yakima.
1170.keyAssumptions:
Sampling sites are representative.

Fish are accurately identified to species.

Instrumentation used in measuring fish is properly calibrated.

Data collected and analyzed represent accurate estimates of the true population.

The Type I and Type II error rates reported adequately detect differences in effect size:  e.g., lack of impact to NTT monitoring variable is not due to lack of statistical power.
1170.dataHandlingConsiderations: There are primarily two data sheets used in the field for sampling within Ecolical Interactions: a fish count datasheet, and a habitat characterization datasheet. Data collected in the field is transfered into an Excel database, peer reviewed, and then submitted into an Access database to check for errors. Data is analyzed in a variety of programs from this point on.
1170.qualityControlConsiderations:
There is always a certain amount of human error involved in the collection, transfer of, and processing of data, so it is essential to have personnel that are well trained and competent in their ability to gather correct information.

Employees initials are included on all datasheets so if a discrepency arises in a particular dataset, individuals may be contacted to verify the information.

Data are processed as quickly as possible, so if there are discrepencies they can be addressed while the date of data collection is recent enough to recall.
1170.reportingConsiderations: Data is entered into an Excel database for ease of handling, transferred into an Access database for error checking and analyzation, and submitted in BPA FORMAT for BPA reviewal.
1170.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration:
During sampling and collection of samples, personnel follow the protocols as outlined by the DFW aquatic invasive species act, as well as BPA's requirements through Pisces.

e.g. Vircon is applied to wading boots and waders before and after accessing a different basin. Balances are calibrated or replaced annually, measuring boards are repaired or replaced annually, backpack electrofishers are maintained to stay in working order, 190 or 200 proof alcohol is used to sterilize any equipment in need of disinfecting.
1170.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Crew leads are responsible for directly managing and assisting in the collection, entering, storage, and submittal of data. 

Crew members assist the Crew lead all tasks listed above.
1170.qualifications: Crew leads are required to attend supervisor training, and have a Scientific Technician 2 or higher job title.
1170.trainingRequirements: Crew leads and crew members receive training for certification in different tasks so as to fulfill requirements outlined by WDFW.
1170.safetyConsiderations: Crew leads and crew members follow protocols outlined by WDFW to ensure proper use of equipment, and to receive the proper training to conduct work tasks in a safe and controlled manner.
1170.fieldScheduleNotes:
Ecological Interactions technicians work 10 hour days Monday through Thursday, so as to maximize effort during the day as time and effort required for sampling fish is high.

Ecological Interactions Biologists work 8 hour days Monday through Friday.
1170.budgetConsiderations:
Within sampling for ecological interactions, more than one projects needs may be satisfied. This reduces the restraint of costs required for current/additional projects, and in turn allows for more data sharing across projects at a lower cost.

Travel costs must always be considered when sampling streams. Streams are typically far away from base of operations, and located in remote areas where the use of a 4x4 vehicle may be required.

Backpack electrofishing equipment is expensive to purchase, repair, or replace. Wading equipment is expensive to purchase, however if maintained will last several years. 

The driftboat electrofisher used for sampling the mainstem Yakima River is expensive to assemble, however is relatively inexpensive to maintain.
1170.name: WDFW / YKFP: Ecological Interactions: Non-Target Taxa of Concern Monitoring

sampleDesigns.title: Rufus Woods Creel Sampling - Colville Confederated Tribes
Rufus Woods Creel Sampling - Colville Confederated Tribes V2.0

1174.backgroundRationale:
Rufus Woods Lake is an 82 km long run-of-the-river reservoir on the Columbia River that was formed by the construction of Chief Joseph Dam.  Currently, the dam has no fish ladders and blocks upstream fish passage.  Grand Coulee Dam forms the upstream end of Rufus Woods Lake.

In 1996, the Colville Tribes, working with Columbia River Fish Farms (an aquaculture facility on Rufus Woods Lake) began a fish release program using Tribal funds to supplement the Rufus Woods Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) fishery.  The current Washington State record Rainbow Trout was caught in Rufus Woods Lake in 2002 (29.6 lbs).  In 2007 and 2008 there were more than 40,000 angler days spent fishing in Rufus Woods annually, making Rufus Woods the most popular fishing destination on the Colville Reservation.  The current Rainbow Trout daily bag limit is two.  The reservoir also contains other sport fish including Walleye (Sander vitreus), Kokanee (Oncorhynchus nerka), Burbot (Lota lota), Lake Whitefish (Coregonus clupeaformis), Smallmouth Bass (Micropterus dolomieu), and Brown Trout (Salmo trutta).

Previous years' preliminary creel data suggest the trophy fishery and catch rates were maintained at artificially high levels due to excessive fish escapement from the aquaculture net pens located within Rufus Woods Lake and not from the Colville Tribes' fish purchases and stocking efforts (Shallenberger 2009).  In early 2014, one of the two aquaculture facilities on Rufus Woods Lake shutdown.  The other facility has greatly reduced its fish escapement and excess feed drift.  As a result, the few bigger Rainbow Trout released by the Tribes' have been unable to sustain historically high catch rates of trophy fish.  Additional studies were conducted to investigate the potential of supplementing the fishery with many smaller Rainbow Trout that could grow within the lake.  However, the majority of Rainbow Trout released only occupied Rufus Woods Lake for one month because of harvest, entrainment and other unidentified causes, making growth of smaller fish to trophy size unlikely (Brown et al. 2011).  Diet and secondary production studies also indicated insufficient food resources are incorporated into Rainbow Trout diets to produce an adequate trophy fishery (Richards et al. 2011).

For these reasons, the goal of the fishery has shifted from a trophy-only fishery to a combined catchable and trophy fishery. To achieve this goal, the release consist of approximately 67% large catchable Rainbow Trout (~0.45 kg per fish, >400 mm total length) to maintain higher catch rates of quality size fish, and approximately 33% larger fish (~15,000 trout at ~>1.5 kg per fish) to provide the opportunity to catch memorable-trophy size Rainbow Trout (size categories based on Brouder et al. 2009).

In order to provide information on the fishery for optimal management, the Colville Tribes has conducted a detailed creel study since 2007.  These protocols have been changed overtime to reflect changes in the fishery (usage and site access locations), project budget, and personnel constraints.
objectives: Estimate total fishing effort (angler-hours and angler days) for shore and boat anglers for all strata.
Estimate average catch and harvest rate (# fish per angler-hour) for all Rainbow Trout and individual sources of Rainbow Trout (when possible) for all strata.
Estimate total catch and harvest for all Rainbow Trout and individual sources of Rainbow Trout (when possible) for all strata.
Estimate harvested fish size statistics (length and weight) for all Rainbow Trout and individual sources of Rainbow Trout (when possible) by month.
1174.keyAssumptions:
Surveys will be conducted from 7:00 am until 5:00 pm, and are assumed to represent catch and effort throughout the rest of the non-sampled complete fishing day (i.e., half-hour before sunrise to half-hour after sunset).

The degree of bias induced by the access-point surveys will be assumed to be negligible based on the lack of anglers viewed at other locations along the shoreline from effort surveys performed from a boat.

The length of an angling trip is assumed to be relatively constant throughout individual strata and anglers are assumed to only make one trip a day.
1174.dataHandlingConsiderations: Field data sheets are scanned into electronic format for backup on a bi-weekly basis. The electronic files are then stored on hard drives two separate physical locations and on a remote server.
1174.qualityControlConsiderations: Data is reviewed by a biologist and entered into spreadsheet format. Another biologist reviews the entered data. Any data issues will be discussed with the survey technician and remedied if possible.
1174.reportingConsiderations: Data will be entered into an spreadsheet format accepted by the analysis program, MiCreel, on a monthly basis. Data will be stored in the StreamNet Data Store.
1174.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Field equipment (e.g., truck, measuring board, tag detection equipment, etc...) is cleaned daily.
1174.rolesAndResponsibilities: The crew leader is responsible for scheduling creel days and scanning data sheets. The crew leader and members conduct creel surveys. The biologists enters and analysis the data.
1174.qualifications: Staff qualifications require the ability to strictly adhere to protocols. Biologist qualifications require knowledge of creel data analysis.
1174.trainingRequirements: Creel staff are trained on survey protocols with an annual refresher course.
1174.safetyConsiderations: Creel surveys are performed outdoors. As such, proper PPE to address the elements must be considered. Additionally, vehicles are driven extensively to conduct the creel surveys and must be operated safely and within the law.
1174.fieldScheduleNotes: Creel days will be randomly selected within each month to sample a minimum of 50% weekday and weekend days. Surveys will be conducted from 7:00 am until 5:00 pm, and are assumed to represent catch and effort throughout the rest of the non-sampled complete fishing day (i.e., half-hour before sunrise to half-hour after sunset). Start location and survey direction (upstream or downstream) will be chosen to maximize the amount of creel time within a day (i.e., least travel time).
1174.budgetConsiderations: All the sites are far apart because the reservoir is approximately 51 miles long. This requires a lot of travel time and costs. Additionally, the number of creel roves is limited by the number of creel staff, and exit surveys could be increased if funding was available.
1174.name: Rufus Woods Lake Creel Survey

sampleDesigns.title: Grassland Restoration Monitoring on the Precious Lands Wildlife Management Area (Buford Parcel)

1178.backgroundRationale:
124 acres of rolling benches were under cultivation for wheat and hay production by the previous owner. These fields were replanted with native grasses and forbs to promote wildlife value. Monitoring plots were established on both a control field (natural bunchgrass community) and a treatment field. Plots were monitored for three years to establish baseline data, and then subsequently every five years. 

While monitoring was initially used to evaluate the baseline condition of the project area, long-term monitoring will continue to help document trends in plant community health, weedy encroachment, limiting factors for wildlife, and identify/monitor areas of habitat degradation.
objectives: Reclamation of the natural floral components native to the area.
1178.keyAssumptions:
1.Personnel are trained in the identification of the local flora as well as familiar with the sampling design.

2.Plots will be monitored at height of growing season (middle of summer) to limit year to year variability.
1178.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are collected and recorded in the field using write-in-the-rain paper data forms. All field data is then transposed onto spreadsheets and stored on the tribe's server for later use by personnel for field reference or annual reports.
1178.qualityControlConsiderations: Collect vouchers of immature or unknown species for identification purposes.
1178.reportingConsiderations: All data forms are scanned and saved on a shared drive for easy access from personnel. Original hard copy is filed in accessible cabinet.
1178.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: 0.5 m2 microplot repainted after each monitoring visit.
1178.rolesAndResponsibilities: 2 people monitoring 100 data frames inside plot
1178.qualifications: One Botanist and an assistant / technician to help with moving measuring tape, recording data values on data form, delineating rebar with flagging for future use.
1178.trainingRequirements: Botanist must be familiar with local flora in all stages of growth
1178.safetyConsiderations: Personnel are trained in basic first aid and CPR, and are aware of hazards in the area such as snakes, and to detect symptoms of heat stress.
1178.fieldScheduleNotes: Monitoring is performed in July every 5 years. A maximum of two days is required for two people to complete one quadrant survey (there are two quadrants; control and treatment).
1178.budgetConsiderations: Overnight stay is required for two people to complete entire survey.
1178.name: Grassland Restoration Monitoring on the Precious Lands Wildlife Management Area

sampleDesigns.title: Vegetation/Habitat Monitoring - Nez Perce Tribe

1179.backgroundRationale:
Under the Northwest Power Planning Act, the Bonneville Power Administration was mandated to mitigate for wildlife habitat losses. In order to do that BPA must be able to measure the amount and quality of habitat lost and gained through their activities, including the Precious Lands project. The accounting system adopted by BPA is a habitat modeling strategy known as a Habitat Evaluation Procedure (HEP) developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. This procedure uses models to measure the quality of a specific habitat for target wildlife species. The models are based on key habitat parameters (ex. shrub height, snag density, or distance to water) and provide a measure of the habitat quality for that particular species. One product of HEP is a quantitative evaluation of habitat quality that is provided in terms of a Habitat Unit (HU). One acre of optimum habitat equals one HU. This HU accounting system is used to determine the amount of credit BPA receives for the land being protected.

While HSI models were initially used to evaluate the baseline condition of the Precious Lands Area, long-term monitoring will be conducted based on HEP data collection procedures, but not limited to particular wildlife variables. For example, percent microbiotic crust cover and percent bare ground are recorded for microplots in grasslands while the number of woody debris >4" diameter is recorded for transects in riparian and conifer cover types. Surveys will be used to assess long-term trends in plant community health, weedy encroachment, limiting factors for wildlife and identify/monitor areas of habitat degradation.
objectives: Develop trend data for plant community health and weed encroachment from long term monitoring of HEP transects.
Determine limiting factors for wildlife.
Identify and monitor areas of habitat degradation.
1179.keyAssumptions:
1. Personnel will be properly trained in HEP monitoring as well as identification of local flora.

2. Transects, when revisited, will be run at the same time of year and phenological stage of the indicator plants as the baseline transects.
1179.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are collected and recorded in the field by hand using paper data forms and pencil. We use write-in-the-rain paper to ensure legibility. Field data is stored in house as hard copies and all data are tranferred to computer spreadsheets and copied to the tribe's server for backup purposes.
1179.qualityControlConsiderations: 100' measuring tape should be run as close to the original line/azimuth as possible to ensure measurement of the same area. Ideally, transects should be measured and data analyzed by the same person to eliminate any bias
1179.reportingConsiderations: Four letter codes for the shrub and tree components must follow standardized formats.
1179.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Densitometer needs cleaned after each HEP transect. 0.5 m2 microplot needs repainted after all HEPs are completed for the season.
1179.rolesAndResponsibilities: A biologist and an assistant to help run measuring tape and record data.
1179.qualifications: Key personnel must be trained in HEP techniques and proficient at identifying local flora.
1179.trainingRequirements: Training in Botany; HEP training courses for all personnel.
1179.safetyConsiderations: Terrain and access issues are routinely encountered in the project area. Wilderness first aid certification is required. A satellite phone is necessary for safety in case of injury or other emergencies encountered in remote canyon grasslands.
1179.fieldScheduleNotes: HEP plots average three to four plots a year starting in mid June and running into September, due to the proximity of sites coupled with the remoteness of the area.
1179.budgetConsiderations: There are many specialized equipment needs for this project (see equipment list) as well as a satellite phone. Some sites require use of ATVs. Sites are located so far apart, travel costs increase and personnel may need to stay overnight which will incur costs (tents, camp equipment, travel trailers, motel rooms and food). Anybody performing HEP must be trained at a cost including any refresher training.
1179.name: Habitat Evaluation on the Precious Lands Project

sampleDesigns.title: Collect fall Chinook diet data - US Geological Survey (USGS)
Beach seine wild fall Chinook salmon subyearlings in 2016/2017 - US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS), cloned for Study Design 1180
Analyze/Interpret the 1992-2016 beach seining and tagging data - US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS), cloned for Study Design 1180
PIT tag detection at Lower Granite Dam - US Geological Survey (USGS), cloned for Study Design 1180
Beach seine wild fall Chinook salmon subyearlings in 2018/2019 - US Geological Survey (USGS), cloned for Study Design 1180
Monitoring early life history attributes of Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon WSE 131946, cloned for Study Design 1180
Monitoring early life history attributes of Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon WSE 132435, cloned for Study Design 1180
Beach seine wild fall Chinook salmon subyearlings in 2018/2019 - US Geological Survey (USGS), cloned for Study Design 1180
Analyze/Interpret the 1992-2016 beach seining and tagging data - US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS), cloned for Study Design 1180
PIT tag detection at Lower Granite Dam - US Geological Survey (USGS), cloned for Study Design 1180
Analyze fall Chinook diets - US Geological Survey (USGS)
Collect fall Chinook diet data - US Geological Survey (USGS)

1180.backgroundRationale: Maintenance of the life history characteristics of the natural juveniles that are part of the Snake River fall Chinook salmon population/ESU is important for assessing the diversity aspect of the draft recovery plan and assessing actions to recover the population/ESU.  Specifically, adding additional years to the existing 1992-2014 data set collected on timing of juvenile presence, size, growth, and dispersal timing into the reservoir provides information for assessing evidence for density-dependent phenotypic change in Chinook Salmon subyearlings native to an 8th order river.
objectives: (5) Document trends in rate of downstream movement of natural juveniles measured between time of riverine rearing and passage at Lower Granite Dam.
(4) Document trends in passage timing of natural juveniles at Lower Granite Dam.
(3) Document trends in relative abundance of natural fall Chinook salmon juveniles along the shorelines of the free-flowing Snake River upstream of Lower Granite Reservoir.
(2) Document trends in growth of parr in length and weight during rearing along the shorelines of the free-flowing Snake River upstream of Lower Granite Reservoir.
(1) Document trends in time of presence of natural fry and parr along the shorelines of the free-flowing Snake River upstream of Lower Granite Reservoir.
1180.keyAssumptions:
(1) Our frame is representative of the target population.

(2) Changes in timing of fish presence are affected more by changes in fish behavior than by flow-related changes in sampling efficiency.

(3) Growth of juveniles is not strongly affected by PIT tagging.

(4) Catch per unit effort reflects changes in abundance to a greater extent than flow-related changes in sampling efficiency.

(5) Collection probability at Lower Granite Dam is affected more by outflow and spill than by fish size.
1180.dataHandlingConsiderations: Seining and tagging data are recorded in a PIT tag file built at each seining site as the fish are processed. Each tagging file is stored on the hard drive of a lap top and backed up on a flash drive. Each Monday the data are transcribed from the tagging files using a macro into a master data base in Excell. The master data base is stored on a hard drive and external drives of two personal computers in separate offices, and on the server on a third office. The same backup process is followed for analyses and reports.
1180.qualityControlConsiderations: Length is plotted against weight to check for transcription errors. Growth in fork length results are are examined for negative numbers to check for transcription erros as subyearling Chinook salmon do not become smaller in fork length as the become older. The number of fish tagged and recaptured and the associated tagging and recapture data in the master data base are checked against PTAGIS. Release and detection dates of PIT-tagged fish are compared to insure the fish were not detected before release. Such would be the case if incorrect release dates were recorded for a PIT tagged fish. All flow data used to estimate collection probability are plotted against date to check for continuity across the season. CPUE calculations are examined each year to insure that each sampling site is represented each week of the season to insure all site data have been recorded unless a site was not sampled. Rate of downstream movement values for individual fish are sorted in ascending order and examined for outliers.
1180.reportingConsiderations: Results are presently included in two forms to the Bonneville Power Administration. (1) Annual reports covering findings each calendar year are written each spring and posted on the BPA reporting site. (2) Reports on how the project addressed needs identified in the current Biological Opinion are also written and posted annually on the BPA reporting site.
1180.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: All equipment is expected weekly for invasive species of plants and invertebrates during washing and disinfection. Scales for weighing fish are calibrated annually.
1180.rolesAndResponsibilities: The project leader writes proposals, administers the project, supervises the field crew, proofs data, analyzes data, and writes reports and peer-reviewed articles. The field crew supervisor schedules field activites, drives the boat, compiles the data. Two field crew members assist in field operations and maintain equipment.
1180.qualifications: The project leader has a B.S, M.S., and PhD in Fisheries Science All other crew members typically have a B.S. in Fisheries or related natural resources field. The field crew supervisor must have extensive experience operating boats on large rivers.
1180.trainingRequirements: Each crew member is required to pass two motorboat safety courses offered by the Department of Interior and update their certification every two years.
1180.safetyConsiderations: Each week the field crew supervisor provides the project leader with a sampling schedule. Each evening the field crew supervisor checks in with the project leader. All crew members wear life jackets. Each boat is fully equipped with safety devices.
1180.name: Monitoring early life history attributes of Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon

sampleDesigns.title: Count fall Chinook salmon redds in 2016 - US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS)
COPY: Count fall Chinook salmon redds in 2018 - US Geological Survey (USGS)
Count fall Chinook salmon redds - US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS)
Count fall Chinook salmon redds in the Snake River - US Geological Survey (USGS)

1181.backgroundRationale: Redd counts in large rivers can help to describe the spatial distribution of spawning salmon.  Increases in the spatial distribution of redds can suggest that the a given population/ESU is responding positively to implemented actions.  Long-term redd- count data can also inform the spatial criteria for recovery established recovery plans as well as provide important data for modeling efforts identified such plans.
objectives: (1)Count redds in shallow water
(2)Count redds in deep water
1181.keyAssumptions:
(1) Our frame represents our target population.

(2) Every redd in shallow water is counted

(3) Every redd at a deep water site selected for sampling is counted
1181.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are recorded in hard copy in the field and transcribed to a spread sheet in the office. Each annual spreadsheet is copied into a master file spanning the years 1987 to present. All electronic files are backed up on external drives on three personal computers in three separate offices and on two servers located in two separate offices.
1181.qualityControlConsiderations: One experienced observer (1992 to present) counts the redds from the helicopter, while a second staff member records counts and GPS coordinates. Questionable shallow water redds are ground truthed. Counts are not made when the water is too turbid or the weather is inclement. Highly concentrated deep water redds are video taped and the counts are finalized in the office.
1181.reportingConsiderations: One annual report is submitted to the Bonneville Power Administration annually. One report is also submitted that addresses how counting redds met criteria established in a Biological Opinion.
1181.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Boats and equipment used for deep water surveys are checked for invasive plants and invertebrates, and washed weekly.
1181.rolesAndResponsibilities: A project leader writes proposals, administers the project, supervises the field crew, proofs data, tabulates redd counts, and writes reports and peer-reviewed artilces. A field crew member records data in the helicopter. A field crew supervisory runs the boat and schedules the deep water surveys. A field crew member takes underwater video and records data.
1181.qualifications: The project leader has a BS, MS, and PhD in Fisheries Science The field crew supervisor has a BS and in Fish and Wildlife Management Field crew usually have BS degrees in Fisheries or a related natural resources field.
1181.trainingRequirements: Motor boat training through the Department of Interior is mandatory and refresher courses must be taken every two years. Several training courses are required to fly in the helicopter and those courses must be refreshed every 2 years.
1181.safetyConsiderations: The helicopter flights are monitored remotely in real time to insure any mishaps are observed immediately. The field crew supervisor provides the project leader with a weekly sampling schedule and contacts the project leader each evening to confirm a safe return. In the absence of such notification, the project leader sends out a response team the following morning to provide assistance as needed.
1181.name: Counting Salmon Redds in Large Rivers

1182.backgroundRationale:
Photographs of habitat status can help monitor long-term trends in plant cover, weed invasion, and disturbances. Plant height, size, flowering effort, and levels of herbivory are some of the conditions that will be used to document general health trends of vegetative communities. Photo points can be useful in documenting effects and subsequent succession after flood, fire, grazing, or mass wasting events, and can quantitatively monitor habitat and long-term plant growth (Skovlin and Thomas 1995). They will be used to establish baseline conditions and stature of plant communities.

In addition to general habitat trends, succession on newly reclaimed sites will be documented photographically annually for the first 3 years, and every 5 years thereafter.
objectives: Document any changes in vegetation cover, density, and composition over time
1182.keyAssumptions:
Photos are taken at approximately the same time each revisit

The same azimuth is used to duplicate original photo orientation
1182.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data (digital photographs) will be collected in the field using quality digital cameras. All photos will be kept on file by the program's monitoring entity. Comparison data will be organized and submitted in annual reports to the Bonneville Power Administration.
1182.qualityControlConsiderations: Rebar was placed in the ground along the azimuth randomly selected to maintain the correct bearing for future monitoring.
1182.reportingConsiderations: Al photos are stored in office file cabinets.
1182.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Camera lens are cleaned before any image is taken. Camera settings must match original stings on baseline image.
1182.rolesAndResponsibilities: Field personnel who is familiar with the area.
1182.qualifications: Field leader must be able to utilize a GPS unit, compass, and a camera
1182.safetyConsiderations:
All field personnel to complete a basic first aid/CPR course. 

Wilderness training offered every 3 years.
1182.fieldScheduleNotes: There are many photo points established on Precious Lands, often located in remote settings. Most will consume a whole day.
1182.budgetConsiderations:
Travelling to and from sites incurs costs from vehicle maintenance and fuel.

For safety considerations, two people will monitor sites (wages).
1182.name: Nez Perce Tribe Condition Photo Points; Documenting Habitat Change

sampleDesigns.title: Silene Population Monitoring - Nez Perce Tribe 1

1186.backgroundRationale:
Spalding’s catchfly (Silene spaldingii) is a rare plant endemic to the bunchgrass, sagebrush-steppe, and open pine communities of the inland Pacific Northwest. Large portions of these habitats have been eliminated by cultivation or degraded by livestock grazing. Spalding’s catchfly was listed as Threatened by the U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service in 2001.

During a noxious weed survey conducted in 2003, a Wallowa Resources employee located what he thought was a small population of Silene spaldingii above Joseph Creek on the Precious Lands Wildlife Area in Northeast Oregon. Tribal botanists returned to the site on July 14, 2004 and confirmed that he had indeed located the first population of Spaulding’s catchfly on the Tribal lands in Oregon.
objectives: To collect seeds for cryopreservation.
Continuous monitoring to learn more about reproduction, dormancy and pollination of this plant.
1186.keyAssumptions:
1.Personnel can properly identify Spalding's Catchfly.

2.Sampling twice during the growing season will capture all plants present within the plots, with enough information collected to inform introduction, dormancy and pollination of this plant.
1186.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are collected and recorded in the field by hand using paper data forms and pencil. Use write-in-the-rain paper to ensure legibility. The data are summarized into spreadsheet tables and stored on the tribe's server for later reference.
1186.qualityControlConsiderations: Rebar was placed on each side of monitoring plots to ensure each 1 m2 section is the same for all revisits. Flagging was placed on each corner of plot with a different color flagging used for the starting point.
1186.rolesAndResponsibilities: A botanist and an assistant to help run measuring tape and record data.
1186.qualifications: Key personnel must be trained in the identification of Spalding's Catchfly in all phases of growth.
1186.trainingRequirements: To identify Spalding's Catchfly in rosette, vegetative, and reproductive form.
1186.safetyConsiderations: Terrain and access issues are routinely encountered in the project area. Wilderness first aid certification is required. A satellite phone is a must to be able to contact help in case of emergency.
1186.fieldScheduleNotes: Access points to the plant's population is very remote, either requiring landowner permission or use of ATVs.
1186.budgetConsiderations:
Plant population is located so remote, travel costs increase and personnel may need to stay overnight which will incur costs (tents, camp equipment, travel trailers, motel rooms and food). 

Costs for a satellite phone.
1186.name: Silene spaldingii Monitoring on the Precious Lands Wildlife Management Area

sampleDesigns.title: Assessment of benthic macroinvertebrates in select Upper Columbia and Sanpoil Subbasin streams - Colville Confederated Tribes

1192.backgroundRationale:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy.

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Many of the Level II attributes are related to physical habitat and flow; however, there are also fish, macroinvertebrate, and water chemistry attributes. Benthic macroinvertebrate community data is limited for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, particularly in smaller streams.

While status and trends monitoring is not currently an LRHIP objective, we wanted to collect baseline information on the benthic macroinvertebrate communities in a manner that would allow for future monitoring. With the future monitoring option in mind, we developed our protocol so that it was consistent with other monitoring programs in the Basin, such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (Bouwes et al. 2011) and the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP) (Terraqua Inc. 2009).
objectives: Describe benthic macroinvertebrate communities for use in EDT model development that will aid in habitat restoration and protection prioritization.
Provide a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of benthic macroinvertebrate communities.
Provide baseline benthic macroinvertebrate data sets for use in EDT model development.
1192.keyAssumptions: Sample sizes are large enough to provide high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings.
1192.dataHandlingConsiderations:
Data will be recorded on paper (waterproof) forms in the field in pencil. Data forms will be reviewed for completeness at the end of each data collection activity (e.g. electrofishing pass) and at the end of each day. Completed data forms will be returned to the office at the end of each field trip. In the event of extended field trips, data sheets will be placed in a designated folder and secured in a designated vehicle or lodging location. Completed data forms will not be transported back into the field. Upon return to the office all completed data forms will be scanned as a portable document file (.pdf), saved on a computer hard drive, and backed up on a server or portable storage device (e.g. USB hard drive). The original data form will then be filed in a designated secure location until such time as the data can be entered into the database. If scanning is not available, the original data form will be photocopied and the duplicate version will be filed in a separate designated secure location, preferably in a separate building. 
Original data will be transcribed from the paper forms into an electronic database. Personnel will initial each data form that they enter in the upper right hand corner. During data entry, the database will be saved on a regular basis (15 min.). The database will also be backed up on a server or portable storage device (e.g. USB hard drive).
1192.qualityControlConsiderations: All of the data are re-examined for quality assurance analysis. The quality assurance analysis procedure consists of comparing every data point entered into the excel database spreadsheet to the original datasheets.  Data from each site are separated into groups to isolate various types of data (e.g. monument, discharge, fish) and error rates are provided for each of these data groups.  Missing comments are not considered as data entry errors.  Tables are constructed identifying the number of data points for each data group within the database and a total error rate for each DCE is calculated.  Site table data is common to all of the year’s data.  The data are examined for evidence of systematic errors that may have been repeated throughout the database. There are times when data cannot be collected.  This should be noted in the comment field to distinguish it from mistakenly missed data. Year to year comparisons of error rates are completed identify temporal variation in error rates and systematic errors.
1192.reportingConsiderations: Results will be reported in BPA annual technical reports, following their formatting requirements.
1192.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: All nets, waders, and boots were used exclusively in the Lake Roosevelt basin. Equipment was dried between sampling efforts, any attached detritus was removed.
1192.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Lead Field Biologist - day to day project oversight and implementation, field crew training and supervision, data collection, data analysis, reporting

Lead  Field Technician - day to day supervision of technicians, field crew training and general oversight, data collection, data entry, QA/QC, equipment procurement and maintenance

Field Technician - data collection, data entry, equipment construction and maintenance
1192.qualifications:
Lead Field Biologist - minimum Bachelors Degree from and accredited university; experience implementing electrofishing studies, supervising field crews, collecting data efficiently and accurately, and analyzing fisheries data; knowledge of scientific method

Lead  Field Technician - minimum High School diploma and 48 months experience at the general field technician level; experience implementing electrofishing studies, supervising field crews, collecting data efficiently and accurately, and procuring and maintaining field equipment; knowledge of scientific method

Field Technician - minimum High School diploma; prefer experience implementing electrofishing studies, collecting scientific data, and maintaining field equipment; knowledge of scientific method
1192.trainingRequirements: All personnel are required to complete protocol specific training.
1192.safetyConsiderations: All field staff will maintain current First Aid/CPR certification. Safety equipment, such as fire extinguishers, accident signs, and first aid kits, will be carried in all vehicles. All sample preservative will be labeled appropriately and MSDS information will be retained with the samples and preservative.
1192.fieldScheduleNotes: The surveys are conducted during low flow periods, primarily between early July and mid-October. Access in areas with high proportion of private land ownership may be difficult. Recommend beginning to get access lined up well before sampling is scheduled to begin.
1192.budgetConsiderations: The most expensive equipment are the nets and frames, which can be somewhat difficult to source..
1192.name: LRHIP - Sanpoil and Upper Columbia Subbasin Benthic Macroinvertebrate Monitoring

1194.safetyConsiderations: All field staff will maintain current First Aid/CPR certification. Safety equipment, such as fire extinguishers, accident signs, and first aid kits, will be carried in all vehicles.
1194.fieldScheduleNotes: The surveys are conducted during low flow periods, primarily between early July and mid-October. Access in areas with high proportion of private land ownership may be difficult. Recommend beginning to get access lined up well before sampling is scheduled to begin.
1194.budgetConsiderations: The most expensive equipment is the water flow meter.
