sampleDesigns.title: Egg-to-fry survival study - Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW)
Estimating spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival and development over large temporal and spatial scales WSE 132455
Estimating spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival and development over large temporal and spatial scales in the Methow River Basin
Estimating spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival and development over large temporal and spatial scales in the Entiat River Basin
Estimating spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival and development over large temporal and spatial scales in the Entiat River Basin

1195.backgroundRationale: Egg-to-fry survival is one of the major factors thought to limit freshwater production and recovery of Chinook salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha and other salmon populations (Reiser and White 1988; Peterson and Quinn 1996; DeVries 1997). Despite being critical data that is needed to assist with efforts to recover threatened and endangered salmonid populations, adequate estimates of egg-to-fry survival for Chinook salmon do not currently exist (Healey 1991; Bradford 1995). This lack of information is likely due to the difficulty in measuring Chinook salmon and other salmonid egg-to-fry survival in the field because they deposit their eggs in the gravel during periods that make extensive field research difficult (Quinn 2005). This is particularly true for Chinook salmon, which spawn in large rivers with deeper and swifter water than most other salmon, and for which developing embryos remain in the gravel throughout the winter and early spring when it is difficult to sample (Quinn 2005). Therefore, many of the existing studies of Chinook salmon egg-to-fry survival have occurred in a laboratory setting (Jensen et al. 2009) and may not adequately represent egg-to-fry survival in the natural environment. This work provides estimates of survival and development, and an assessment of factor potentially affecting either metric, over large temporal and spatial scales, in the natural environment. See Johnson et al (2012) for a complete explanation of the methodology associated with this protocol
objectives: Investigate the extent to which environmental factors such as scour, redd superimposition, fines sediment infiltration, and temperature may influence survival and development spatially and temporally.
Estimate relative developmental stage at recovery among and within primary spawning locations of the target watershed, within and among years, while controlling for parental effects.
Estimate relative spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival among and within primary spawning locations of the target watershed, within and among years, while controlling for parental effects.
1195.keyAssumptions:
1) Selected study locations are spatially and temporally representative of the population

2) Environmental conditions within buried Whitlock-Vibert egg boxes are representative of conditions in the surrounding environment (see Wesche et al. 1989; Garrett and Bennett 1996).

3) Environmental conditions experienced among study years sufficiently represent inter-annual variation within the target watershed.

4) A simple thermal sums model is sufficient to calculate duration of deployment such that developmental stage at recovery is similar among study areas; which may differ substantially in the rate and magnitude of temperature unit delivery to the egg pocket.
1195.dataHandlingConsiderations: We recommend that datasheets, many having relocation data necessary for recovery efforts, be copied rather than taken back into the field during subsequent study site visits.
1195.qualityControlConsiderations: Previous work has suggested that normal error rates associated with data collection and entry do not sizably affect estimates common in the field of fisheries, but that some degree of standardized review is necessary to identify instances of egregious error (Johnson et al. 2009). Efforts are made to ensure a consistent level of data quality through a combination of redundancy in field measures and data entry protocol. Field data (e.g. triangulation measures, redd morphology, distance to the nearest natural redd, site accessibility), are monitored through repeated site visits prior to box recovery. Raw data sheets are then stored in a specified cabinet within the Ellensburg WDFW field office until they can be entered into electronic format. Because data entry is often completed by personnel with varying experience, the vast majority is entered twice, and subjected to a formal cross check by an experienced technician or project biologist. This crosscheck may be in the form of a Read Aloud check, or an Excel based spreadsheet comparison. Reviewed data are then stored locally on the WDFW Ellensburg Server and on the WDFW Olympia S-drive; both of which are backed up nightly.
1195.reportingConsiderations:
AFS format
Reports are generated for each study year.
1195.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration:
Virkon solution is used to minimize the potential transfer of pathogens between watersheds:
See WDFW Policy 5310: Managing Invasive Species (attached)
AND WDFW Invasive Species Management Protocols (attached)
1195.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Crew lead: ensuring crew safety, ensuring that sampling protocols are closely followed.
Crew: ensuring that sampling protocols are closely followed.
1195.qualifications:
Crew leads should have technical fisheries and practical field sampling experience, as well as direct experience with the EF protocol, AND the ability to effectively identify and manage safety concerns. Snorkeling certification is required of at least one crew member during recovery efforts.
Crew members must have the ability to strictly adhere to sampling protocols, and the ability to work under generally unfavorable environmental conditions (e.g. high flow), particularly during recovery efforts.
1195.trainingRequirements:
For egg box stocking events, training is achieved through a hands on walk through under the  supervision of experienced personnel, normally conducted at the first study site. Crew leads must ensure that field protocols are closely followed. due to the spatial distance among study sites in most projects, crew leads must also have experience necessary to make suitable adjustments in the field with minimal oversight.
At the time of recovery, high flow conditions are common. At least one member of the recovery team must be snorkel certified. The use of a weight belt may be necessary. Crew leads must have the ability to identify and assess potential safety concerns prior to recovery attempts.
1195.safetyConsiderations: Potential for high flow conditions while attempting recovery.
1195.fieldScheduleNotes: Flexibility in scheduling must be maintained in order to 1) place egg boxes at a time that corresponds to natural spawning activity, and 2) ensure recovery through a range of  forecasted dates, which are dependent on temperature delivery through the incubation period.
1195.budgetConsiderations: The ability to successfully recover egg boxes can be subject to environmental conditions present at the time of forecasted development. Therefore, it is possible that recoveries may be either delayed, or under the worst of circumstances, abandoned primarily due to high flow conditions which might compromise the safety of the researchers conducting the work.
1195.name: Estimating spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival and development over large temporal and spatial scales

sampleDesigns.title: Operate and maintain Wind River Gage - US Forest Service (USFS): Wind River

1196.backgroundRationale: The Wind River Watershed Project is a multi-agency watershed-scale effort to restore wild Wind River steelhead through habitat restoration and a robust RM and E program.  Streamflow measurements on the Wind River are used to help manage juvenile traps, and to design and monitor habitat work in the drainage.
objectives: Provide hourly streamflow data available in realtime.
1196.keyAssumptions: Stream stage measurements can be used to approximate stream discharge using an established rating curve developed at the monitoring location.
1196.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data are reported from a remotely operated data logger via GOES satellite
1196.qualityControlConsiderations: Direct lowflow discharge measurements are completed each year to validate the rating curve
1196.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: Instrumentation is maintained and checked for operation 2-4 times per year
1196.rolesAndResponsibilities: Instrumentation maintenance and data collection are contracted out
1196.fieldScheduleNotes: Lowflow discharge measurements are made in September/October yearly to validate or update the rating curve for this site.
1196.budgetConsiderations: We use an abandoned USGS gage house for equipment housing and security.
1196.name: Discharge Measurement

sampleDesigns.title: Sanpoil River Water Quality - Colville Confederated Tribes
Sanpoil River Water Temperature - Colville Confederated Tribes
Water Temperature Monitoring - Colville Confederated Tribes
Water Temperature Analysis - Colville Confederated Tribes

1202.backgroundRationale:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish RM&E project is a Columbia River Fish Accord project that began in 2008. The primary goal for the Resident Fish RM&E Project is to conserve, enhance and restore native fish populations in the blocked area above Grand Coulee Dam in Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries, and where appropriate provide opportunities for subsistence harvest by the Colville Tribal members and recreational anglers. The current work of the RM&E project will focus on the protection and conservation of Redband Trout populations on the Colville Confederated Tribes Reservation, with a focus on the Sanpoil River.

Rainbow trout are a focal species in the Sanpoil Subbasin under the Intermountain Province Subbasin Plan (IMP) due to their recreational value as a sport fish and their cultural significance to the CCT (Gillin and Pizzimenti 2004). The Columbia River Redband Trout are a subspecies of Rainbow TInrout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992; McLellan and Lee 2010). Effective fisheries management of redband trout requires an understanding of population structure, complex historical management activities, geography, and life history strategies ( McCusker et al. 2000; Spidle et al. 2003; Spruell et al. 2003; Small et al. 2006;2007).
 
In 2010, the CCT implemented a Redband Trout stock assessment project in the Sanpoil River (McLellan and Lee 2010).  The project plans to implement four primary tasks which include monitoring abundance, monitoring recruitment, monitoring harvest, and monitoring escapement to assist with management decisions. The development of a multi-year data set will enable managers to monitor trends over time and address potential limiting factors.  Water temperature monitoring is required to understand limiting factors and movement patterns.
objectives: Collect continuous surface water temperature at fish trap locations in the Sanpoil River.
1202.keyAssumptions: The temperature data (~ 1m^2) collected at the logger location is representative of the water temperature within the entire reach it is located.
1202.dataHandlingConsiderations: All data are downloaded electronically to prevent transcription errors. Individual HOBOware files are stored in a hierarchy of folders organized by geographic area, basin and stream. HOBOware files are exported as .CSV files and stored in a Microsoft Access database to facilitate future query and analysis. Data are examined for outliers or suspect data and noted in a comments column. All data is stored in the CCT Resident Fisheries database and backed up digitally in multiple locations.
1202.qualityControlConsiderations: We calibrate all temperature loggers prior to deployment. All data are downloaded electronically to prevent transcription errors. Data are examined for outliers.
1202.reportingConsiderations: Reporting occurs in annual progress reports submitted to BPA.
1202.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: The use of all equipment is restricted to individual watersheds to prevent spread of invasive species.All temperature loggers are checked for accuracy prior to deployment.
1202.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Crew lead is responsible for ensuring that temperature loggers are located, deployed and downloaded correctly. Will ensure that data are backed up digitally in the field and transferred to office computers and program database ASAP. QA/QC data and maintain database of "clean" data. 

Crew members will download temperature loggers in the field. Temperature loggers will be relocated within the immediate area if changing environmental conditions suggest risk of dewatering or becoming buried.
1202.qualifications:
Crew lead should have working knowledge of interface software and data management tools (Excel, Access).

Crew member should be able to identify issues with loggers in the field and download/launch them. Ability to work in adverse environmental conditions.
1202.trainingRequirements: Crew Lead and Crew members should be familiar with  launch and download routine of temperature loggers before field deployment.
1202.safetyConsiderations: Adverse weather conditions are sometimes present. Loggers are generally inaccessible during high flows and periods of ice cover.
1202.fieldScheduleNotes: Temperature loggers should be deployed during periods of low flow to prevent air exposure of the logger. Data loggers can be downloaded and maintained as long as they are accessible. Periods of high flow or ice cover may make it dangerous or difficult to access loggers.
1202.budgetConsiderations: Individual loggers are relatively inexpensive (<$100 ea.) as are deployment methods. Primary expenses are incurred from staff and vehicle travel time when logger site locations are relatively far apart and in remote areas requiring travel on foot.
1202.name: CCT Resident Fish _ RM&E Temperature Monitoring

1209.backgroundRationale:
NOTE: The details in this protocol have been revised and are now contained in multiple protocols. Full details can now be found in protocol IDs: 518, 2101, & 2102; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/518; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/2101; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/2102

The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Work conducted under this protocol will provide reach specific temperature,  water, chemistry and stream discharge data to be used to rate EDT Level II attributes associated with each data type.These data will also facilitate analysis of spatial patterns and variance in stream temperature, water chemistry, and discharge among multiple watersheds in the Sanpoil and Upper Columbia River Subbasins
objectives: Describe stream water temperature and chemistry and stream discharge for use in habitat restoration and protection prioritization.
Provide baseline water temperature and chemistry and stream discharge data sets for use in EDT model development.
Provide a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of stream water temperature and chemistry and discharge.
1209.dataHandlingConsiderations:
All temperature data are downloaded electronically to prevent transcription errors. Individual HOBOware files are stored in a hierarchy of folders organized by geographic area, basin and stream. HOBOware files are exported as .CSV files and stored in a Microsoft Access database to facilitate future query and analysis. Data are examined for outliers or suspect data and noted in a comments column. 

Water chemistry and discharge data will be recorded on paper (waterproof) forms in the field in pencil. Data forms will be reviewed for completeness at the end of each data collection activity (e.g. sample measurement) and at the end of each day. Completed data forms will be returned to the office at the end of each field trip. In the event of extended field trips, data sheets will be placed in a designated folder and secured in a designated vehicle or lodging location. Completed data forms will not be transported back into the field. Upon return to the office all completed data forms will be scanned as a portable document file (.pdf), saved on a computer hard drive, and backed up on a server or portable storage device (e.g. USB hard drive). The original data form will then be filed in a designated secure location until such time as the data can be entered into the database. If scanning is not available, the original data form will be photocopied and the duplicate version will be filed in a separate designated secure location, preferably in a separate building.

All data is stored in the CCT Resident Fish and Wildlife database and backed up digitally in multiple locations.
1209.qualityControlConsiderations:
Temperature loggers are calibrated prior to deployment. All loggers are deployed at times of low water to ensure they remain wetted throughout the duration of the study. All data are downloaded electronically to prevent transcription errors. Data are examined for outliers.

Water chemistry and discharge data from all sites are re-examined for quality assurance analysis. The quality assurance analysis procedure consists of comparing every data point entered into the excel database spreadsheet to the original datasheets.  Data from each site are separated into groups to isolate various types of data (e.g. monument, discharge, fish) and error rates are provided for each of these data groups.  Missing comments are not considered as data entry errors.  Tables are constructed identifying the number of data points for each data group within the database and a total error rate for each DCE is calculated.  Site table data is common to all of the year’s data.  The data are examined for evidence of systematic errors that may have been repeated throughout the database. There are times when data cannot be collected, this should be noted in the comment field to distinguish it from mistakenly missed data. Year to year comparisons of error rates are completed identify temporal variation in error rates and systematic errors.
1209.reportingConsiderations: Reporting occurs in annual progress reports submitted to BPA.
1209.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration:
All loggers are deployed in one location for their entire life. Thus, there is no risk of transfer of invasive species among streams or basins. The use of all other equipment is restricted to individual watersheds to prevent spread of invasive species.All temperature loggers are checked for accuracy prior to deployment.

All water quality meters (Extech DO Meter, PCS Testr35 MultiParameter, and LaMotte Alkalinity Testing kit) were calibrated daily to the standards outline in unit descriptions provided by the manufacturer. 

Water sample bottles were supplied and sterilized by Aquatic Research water testing organization.

The water velocity meter, Marsh McBirney flow meter, was calibrated to the standards outline in unit descriptions provided by the manufacturer.

All boots and waders were used exclusively within the Lake Roosevelt basin. Boots and waders were dried between sampling efforts, any attached detritus was removed.
1209.rolesAndResponsibilities:
Lead Field Biologist - day to day project oversight and implementation, field crew training and supervision, data collection, data analysis, reporting 

Lead Field Technician - day to day supervision of technicians, field crew training and general oversight, data collection, data entry, QA/QC, equipment procurement and maintenance 

Field Technician - data collection, data entry, equipment construction and maintenance
1209.qualifications:
Lead Field Biologist - minimum Bachelors Degree from and accredited university; experience implementing electrofishing studies, supervising field crews, collecting data efficiently and accurately, and analyzing fisheries data; knowledge of scientific method

Lead Field Technician - minimum High School diploma and 48 months experience at the general field technician level; experience implementing electrofishing studies, supervising field crews, collecting data efficiently and accurately, and procuring and maintaining field equipment; knowledge of scientific method 

Field Technician - minimum High School diploma; prefer experience implementing electrofishing studies, collecting scientific data, and maintaining field equipment; knowledge of scientific method
1209.trainingRequirements:
Crew Lead and Crew members should be familiar with  launch and download routine of temperature loggers before field deployment.

All personnel are required to complete protocol specific training.
1209.safetyConsiderations:
All field staff will maintain current First Aid/CPR certification. Safety equipment, such as fire extinguishers, accident signs, and first aid kits, will be carried in all vehicles.

Adverse weather conditions are sometimes present. Loggers are generally inaccessible during high flows and periods of ice cover.

All water quality meter calibration standards will be labeled appropriately and MSDS documentation will be kept with the standards.
1209.fieldScheduleNotes:
Temperature loggers should be deployed during periods of low flow to prevent air exposure of the logger. Data loggers can be downloaded and maintained as long as they are accessible. Periods of high flow or ice cover may make it dangerous or difficult to access loggers.

Water chemistry and discharge sampling is conducted during low flow periods, primarily between early July and mid-October. Access in areas with high proportion of private land ownership may be difficult. Recommend beginning to get access lined up well before sampling is scheduled to begin.
1209.budgetConsiderations:
Individual loggers are relatively inexpensive (<$100 ea.) as are deployment methods. Primary expenses are incurred from staff and vehicle travel time when logger site locations are relatively far apart and in remote areas requiring travel on foot.

Water quality meters can be expensive.

1214.backgroundRationale:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish RM&E project is a Columbia River Fish Accord project that began in 2008. The primary goal for the Resident Fish RM&E Project is to conserve, enhance and restore native fish populations in the blocked area above Grand Coulee Dam in Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries, and where appropriate provide opportunities for subsistence harvest by the Colville Tribal members and recreational anglers. The current work of the RM&E project focuses on the protection and conservation of Redband Trout populations on the Colville Confederated Tribes Reservation.

Rainbow Trout are a focal species in the Sanpoil Subbasin under the Intermountain Province Subbasin Plan (IMP) due to their recreational value as a sport fish and their cultural significance to the CCT (Gillin and Pizzimenti 2004). The Columbia River Redband Trout are a subspecies of rainbow trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992; McLellan and Lee 2010). Effective fisheries management of Redband Trout requires an understanding of population structure, complex historical management activities, geography, and life history strategies (McCusker et al. 2000; Spidle et al. 2003; Spruell et al. 2003; Small and Dean 2006; Small et al. 2007).

In order to properly manage the Redband Trout populations managers require a basic understanding of population dynamics and an understanding of survival in trends during key life-histories.  In 2010 the Colville Tribe began working with regional co-managers to develop a comprehensive plan to monitor the Redband Trout populations in the blocked area. The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (McLellan and Lee 2010) developed a Redband Trout Stock Assessment Plan that could be used by the co-managers to collect key life history information. 

This is the outline the CCT has used to develop the Resident Fish RM&E program to conduct stock assessment study on Redband Trout in the Sanpoil River. The project plans to implement four primary tasks which include monitoring abundance, monitoring recruitment, monitoring harvest, and monitoring escapement to assist with management decisions. The development of a multi-year data set will enable managers to monitor trends over time and address potential limiting factors.

This protocol describes Redband Trout Escapement monitoring in the Sanpoil River.
objectives: The objective of this protocol is to collect, mark and estimate the number of Redband Trout returning to the Sanpoil River to spawn.
1214.keyAssumptions:
Key assumptions for this project include: 

The weir trap set at the mouth of the Sanpoil River captures all sizes of adult Redband Trout entering the river throughout the year.
1214.dataHandlingConsiderations: All data are recorded on water proof paper data sheets or with a field computer. Paper data is entered into Excel or the resident fish database weekly. Data collected on field computers are uploaded to the database at the end of every day.
1214.qualityControlConsiderations: All data is reviewed by the lead filed biologist, then the project manager prior to all analysis or acceptance into the database.
1214.reportingConsiderations: All BPA funded projects utilize the RM&E formatting process developed by BPA for annual reports. Data is summarized for the calendar year (Jan - Dec).
1214.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: All equipment (boots, rain gear, waders, and nets) are properly cleaned and stored after the field season is over.
1214.rolesAndResponsibilities: Project Manager: Manages contracts, SOW, budgets, hiring, study designs, attends meetings, and collaborates with regional groups. Field Biologist: Works with project lead to implement daily field activities, managers technicians, orders all equipment and ensures data is collected properly. Technicians: Works closely with field biologist to ensure data is collected, equipment is maintained, and problems are solved.
1214.qualifications: Field Biologist: Minimum four year accredited college degree. Typically field experience with appropriate methods, experience with data analysis, database management, and writing reports. Preference is given to applicants with boating (electrofishing) experience and PIT tag array design experience. Technicians: Minimum qualifications include: High school diploma, must maintain WA State Drivers license, have a good attendance record, work effectively in multicultural environments, must be willing to work late, weekend/holidays, and be physically fit enough to lift and pull heavy equipment. Preference is given to applicants with fisheries experience.
1214.trainingRequirements: Personnel are trained in first aid and CPR classes, swift water rescue, and obtain WA State boaters card. If available, we attempt to provide access to excel training, word training, leadership training, and access to local conferences.
1214.safetyConsiderations: Field crews that enter the river must wear Coast Guard certified personal flotation devices (PFD's). Only personnel that have passed a swift water rescue course are allowed in the river during high flows.
1214.fieldScheduleNotes: Field equipment schedules are developed in collaboration with the project lead and lead field biologist. All gear is fished when water flows are below 500 cfs. Special care is taken above 500 cfs, usually gear is removed from the water to reduce equipment loss and damage
1214.budgetConsiderations: Initial budgets constraints include designing and purchasing a resistance panel weir.
1214.name: Redband Trout Escapement in the Sanpoil River (2008-109-00)

sampleDesigns.title: Redband Trout Genetics Study - Colville Confederated Tribes
Redband Trout Genetics Analysis - Colville Confederated Tribes
Collect Genetic Tissue Samples from wild Rainbow Trout  in Deep Creek - Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW)

1216.backgroundRationale:
The Columbia River Redband Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdneri are a subspecies of Rainbow Trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains. Their known distribution extends upstream as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992). There is considerable variability in the life history of Columbia River Redband Trout (Redband Trout) including both anadromous (O. mykiss that migrate to the ocean) and potamodromous (O. mykiss that migrate solely within fresh water) forms (Behnke 1992). Recently, potamodromous Redband Trout were estimated to occur in 42% of their historic range with invasive species habitat degradation and fragmentation, and climate change being the primary threats to their long term survival (Muhlfeld 2015). Redband Trout are classified as a sensitive species or species of special concern by several states and federal agencies and the American Fisheries Society Endangered Species Committee (Williams et al. 1989; Muhlfeld et al. 2001).

The construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 eliminated the opportunity for Redband Trout in the Upper Columbia River to express anadromy (Scholz et al. 1985) and likely blocked migration routes and isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous Redband Trout. Lake Roosevelt formed in the impounded portion of the Columbia River behind Grand Coulee Dam and supports important tribal and recreational fisheries. Non-native hatchery Rainbow Trout (McCloud River, California  O. stonei) have been stocked in the upper Columbia River and its tributaries to provide angling opportunities and as mitigation for hydropower related impacts (Stober et al. 1977; Peone et al. 1989). Naturally reproducing Rainbow Trout still occur in the upper Columbia River drainage upstream of Grand Coulee Dam. 

Potamodromy can be divided into four types: fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, lacustrine-adfluvial, and allacustrine (Varley and Gresswell 1988; Northcote 1997). Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries support fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, and lacustrine-adfluvial life history types. All three life history types have also been documented within the Sanpoil River drainage, including a small fall run of lacustrine adfluvial fish (Brown et al. 2013). The Sanpoil is the only documented tributary in Lake Roosevelt supporting fall migrating adult Redband Trout.

Microsatellite DNA analysis conducted on wild-born Rainbow Trout in the upper Columbia River drainage indicated that some stocks were pure Redband Trout (Powell and Faler 2002; Taylor 2002; Small and Dean 2006, 2007; Small et al. 2007). Redband Trout persisted in many tributaries with no history of coastal-lineage hatchery Rainbow Trout introductions and where barriers prevented hatchery fish from moving into tributaries (Small et al. 2007).

The Redband Trout Stock Assessment Project (RTSAP) was initiated in Lake Roosevelt by the three co-managers in 2010, Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW), Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT), and the Spokane Tribe of Indians (STI). One of the objectives of RTSAP study is to develop a basin wide genetic stock inventory of the remnant Redband Trout populations in the Lake Roosevelt watershed. This information will be used by regional fisheries managers to assist with habitat restoration plans, conservation needs, and harvest regulation changes.
objectives: Determine the genetic status (pure, introgressed, or naturalized non-native) of wild trout populations within the Lake Roosevelt watershed.
1216.keyAssumptions:
The tissue samples collected for each population are representative of the entire genetic diversity found within the population and not just a small sample representing siblings.

The 192 SNPs are appropriate for determining Redband Trout population level distinctions.
1216.dataHandlingConsiderations: Data will be processed by the WDFW Genetics Lab, Olympia, Washington
1216.qualityControlConsiderations:
??

Tissue samples will be collected according to WDFW genetics laboratory protocols. Samples will be preserved dry on blotter paper.
1216.reportingConsiderations: Results will be included in annual progress reports.
1216.equipmentCleaningAndCalibration: All equipment will be cleaned and disinfected after each sampling event.
1216.rolesAndResponsibilities: Project lead biologist: responsible for project development, project reporting, budget management, and data quality control. Field biologist: responsible for project implementation, specified data collections, field crew supervision, and equipment ordering. Scientific technicians: responsible for daily data collection, equipment maintenance, and data entry.
1216.qualifications: Project Lead: M.S. degree in fisheries or related discipline and minimum 5 years field experience and supervising technicians. Field Lead: B.S. degree in fisheries or related discipline and field experience with fish trapping preferred Crew Members: H.S. diploma and field experience preferred
1216.trainingRequirements: Crew Lead: Proficient in Microsoft Office (including Excel, Word, Powerpoint), GIS, and statistical software. Trained in operating boats and completion of Motorboat Operator Certification Course. Proficient in regional fish identification and ability to trouble shoot gear and equipment issues. Trained in use of hazardous chemicals.
1216.fieldScheduleNotes: Tissue samples should be collected from adult fish during the upstream spawing migrations, creel surveys on Lake Roosevelt, or collected at multiple locations to ensure the full populations genetic variation is captured.
1216.budgetConsiderations: Genetic analysis is expensive and requires a minimum sample number; however, analysis of collections from each tributary only needs to be conducted once.
1216.name: Upper Columbia River redband trout genetic study

1223.backgroundRationale:
The Grande Ronde River Upper Mainstem summer steelhead population (GRUM) area is 4,239 km2 in size and consists of six MaSAs and seven MiSAs (ICTRT 2010).  Steelhead are widely distributed throughout the population area and occupy all six of the MaSAs and five of the seven MiSAs.  Steelhead spawners are predominantly natural origin, although from 1999-2002, a portion of spawners were comprised of Wallowa Hatchery stock, which were directly released into Catherine Creek and the upper Grande Ronde River (ICTRT 2010).  Although Wallowa stock hatchery fish are still released into portions of the Grande Ronde River subbasin, there have been a significant number of hatchery management changes which have reduced the number of hatchery fish spawning in nature (ICTRT 2010).   The ODFW currently manages the GRUM for natural origin steelhead where hatchery influence is considered negligible.

Index spawning ground surveys began in 1967, and redd counts from annual index area spawning ground surveys and intrinsic potential of spawning habitat were used to estimate abundance of adult summer steelhead (ICTRT 2010).  In 2008, index site surveys were maintained for historical continuity, but the protocol was adjusted, and abundance is now based on a Generalized Random Tessellation Stratified (GRTS) design to achieve a statistically useful dataset (Ruzycki et al. 2008).  Data used for calculating age proportion and proportion hatchery origin spawners (pHOS) are collected by the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR) at three weirs in the GRUM population area.  

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has an obligation under the Sustainable Fisheries Act to restore depleted populations to optimal levels of abundance and productivity (McElhany et al. 2000).  The Viable Salmonid Parameter (VSP) concept can be used to inform management decisions and is used by NOAA to assess the current status of the populations, in terms of extinction risk (ICTRT 2010).  The VSP parameters include abundance, productivity, spatial structure, and diversity.  Natural origin spawner abundance (NOSA) is a measure of abundance and is assessed annually.
objectives: To provide natural origin spawner abundance estimates to NOAA, allowing them to assess the current status of the population.
To provide accurate and up to date metric and indicator data for salmon and steelhead in the Columbia Basin to users via a data exchange network and web applications.
1223.keyAssumptions:
The Grande Ronde Upper Mainstem (GRUM) population is genetically distinct from surrounding populations.

Steelhead spawners in the GRUM are predominantly natural origin since 2002.

Data collection is as accurate as possible and has been quality checked.

Total spawner abundance (TSA) and proportion of hatchery origin spawners (pHOS) are accurate.

pHOS was assumed to be zero prior to 1989.
1223.dataHandlingConsiderations: These abundance and productivity VSP indicators are reported in the format of the Coordinated Assessments Data Exchange Standard (DES).
1223.qualityControlConsiderations: Data is backed up on a local share drive at Northeast-Central Oregon Research and Monitoring (NECORM) in La Grande, Oregon.  Data is also sent as an upload to the ODFW Recovery Tracker, StreamNet, and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Exchange Network and available on the internet.
1223.reportingConsiderations: These abundance and productivity VSP indicators are reported in the format of the Coordinated Assessments Data Exchange Standard (DES), along with methods and changes to methods for those indicators and metrics. Full DES datasets are available for each population by download on the ODFW Salmon and Steelhead Recovery Tracker website (http://odfwrecoverytracker.org) and StreamNet, EPA Exchange.
1223.name: ODFW Grande Ronde Upper Mainstem Summer Steelhead Population NOSA
